reviewText:
Borderlands 2 is a game for those that enjoy the feeling of finding awesome equipment hidden in a massive pile of other stuff.

Sure, you don't NEED to go in-depth with this game.  On the first playthrough you can get by with just picking up gear as you travel along, choosing stuff that looks better than your current gear, and maybe occasionally buying something in the vendor that looks handy.  The deeper you go down the rabbit hole however, the more there is to discover.

The story is decent for a First Person Shooter (albeit one with RPG elements), and dialogue is often amusing to a degree.  Handsome Jack, the main antagonist is a cartoon villain with M rated attitudes.  He believes, or at least pretends to believe that he is the good guy, and you are just a Filthy Bandit.".

reviewText:
Borderlands 2 has a lot of what made the original great. Its a shooter with role playing elements. Players loot enemies to collect gear that best compliments their play style.

If you aren't familiar with BL, the best way to explain this is to take the addicting looting system of Diablo and combine it with the basic elements of an FPS, throwing in some RPG via an inventory and skill tree. That's essentially the mechanics of the game, and it all slams together so well here. You have four basic classes to choose to play from, and each class has three paths to focus on in a skill tree -- this means there's plenty of variation to play. In addition to these basic mechanics, the game is open-world, though it may feel semi-linear as you can only explore on an area-by-area basis (think the opposite of an Elder Scrolls game, where you can walk around the entire map without hitting a loading screen until accessing a dungeon).

I have to say, with combining so many of our favorite gaming formulas, this game has so many highlights. Sometimes I felt like I was playing something akin to Skyrim. Other times, the ambiance of a specific area or the design of a specific feature reminded me of BioShock. And sometimes certain things brought me back to my Fallout 3 days. However, I never forgot I was playing a completely new adventure that easily whisked me away for hours in the unique and captivating world of Pandora. Lastly, I can't forget the guns. No joke, there are millions of guns you can find. It is so satisfying to find a ridiculous weapon and destroy enemies for the next three hours with it, only to find another weapon that is even better.

One thing many BL veterans mentioned is the lack of a good narrative beyond funny one-liners in the original game. I never played Borderlands 1, but I can tell you that in BL 2 the characters are memorable, the writing is well-thought out and downright hilarious, and the story moves at a great pace with scenes of great emotion and other scenes of great sarcasm. This is all coming from someone who is used to epic stories from Final Fantasy or Mass Effect. Also, be sure to keep your ears peeled while you fight the various enemies. They say and do some hilarious things themselves. But seriously, the writing is just super clever.

In conclusion, this is one heck of a game. I feel that it combines the best of so many game genres into a single FPS while adding in a memorable story that motivates you to find out what happens next. Of course, you'll be laughing your face off the entire way.

Shoot McShooty in the face

...but not in the leg

Face Mcshooty also screams something about shooting him in the face but even today, professional Borderlands players are STILL trying to figure out what he means by that. reviewText:
Borderlands 2 is an action role playing first person shooter, developed by Gearbox Software and published by 2k Games in September 2012. It is the second game in the Borderlands series and the sequel to the popular 2009 hit Borderlands 1.

As with the first game, you are able to complete a campaign with the main story quest and optional side missions as one of the four Vault hunters.  All of the key gameplay features are all present, such as online co-op, randomly generated loot and character building elements such as talent trees are all found in Borderlands 2. There has been a game of the year edition released last year which includes all the DLC apart from one.

The gameplay at it's core is the same as Borderlands 1. The focus on randomly generated loot plays a huge part. Each of the characters you have the option to play as have their own specialty, and will bring a feel of originality to each playthrough on either of them.  We also see a new elemental effect in BL2, Slag, this is a substance that increases the damage a target takes if they are covered in it. You will also find Eridium bars as you play the game, these can be used to purchase storage upgrades and increase the amount of ammo you can carry.

We also see an element of customizing how your character looks as well, you can unlock different skins, head designs, colour schemes and vehicle paint jobs.  Another major addition to BL2 is the Badd@ss rank" system; points are awarded for completing certain in-game challenges
date: that in turn award tokens that will allow you to increase your base stats. These stat increases also take effect on all of your other single player characters too.  Also similar to the the original

votesHelpful: but with just a more enhanced look to them. We see the vibrant colour schemes in each zone come to life. Along with better quality textures too.  The style of graphics in Borderlands has always been a huge drawing point for me as there are hardly any other games which pull this style off as well as this.\n\nYour first playthrough Borderlands 2 will have a number of difficult encounters

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Borderlands 2
Original Release: 2012
Genre Tags: FPS; RPG; Cooperative; Lighthearted; Action
My Overall Grade: A+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 30-100 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Optional
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Multiplayer gamers
REVIEWBorderlands 2 is the sequel to the original installment of the franchise. Like the first one, it is a chef-d'oeuvre of gaming. It boasts a masterful blend of FPS and RPG elements with an elaborate loot system to make for truly delectable gameplay. Complementing the gameplay is the unique and self-identifying art style and graphics, the blithe and cartoonish atmosphere, and the lighthearted narrative and zany NPC characters. All of these factors working in concert generate one hell of a gaming experience that should be able to bring pleasure to nearly any gamer out there.

Borderlands 2 plays very much like the first game, except there is just a little bit more of everything. Also, there are numerous small tweaks that go a long way to improve the tiny nuisances of the first installment. It is a direct sequel, but the lighthearted nature of the narrative allows for players to safely not worry about having played the first in order to understand the plot.

At the core of Borderlands 2, we find the same exemplary elements found in the first installment of the franchise. The gameplay is designed to offer both the face-paced action of an FPS with the character progression elements and gameworld massiveness of an RPG. There is an XP system that awards level-ups and ability-boosts. There are scores of quests to complete; some ancillary and others pivotal to the core narrative. There is a crazy world to explore, filled with various interesting NPCs. Enemy spawns and combat occur in real-time, right in the midst of everything else that is going on in the gameworld. There is never a dull moment or a lack of something to be working towards.

Borderlands 2 also has an elaborate and semi-random loot drop system. In the style made popular by games like Diablo, loot spills out of chests, crates, and enemies to pile up on the floor for you to peruse. Much of it will be junk, but you must always keep an eye out for the rare high quality drops. This is the same style used in the first Borderlands, except it has been amplified to offer a much wider variety of goodies. Due to the nature of the stat-progression of the weapons and the sheer variety, you will find yourself experimenting with many more and various weapons than you would in a standard FPS.

With Borderlands 2 comes the return of the self-identifying art style that was made iconic in the first game; except the graphics are more crisp and detailed in this installment. The graphics fit the theme of the game with perfection, as they expertly relay the feeling of zany, cartoonish raucousness that the game is striving to evoke. This atmosphere sets the tone for the burlesquing narrative which never wastes an opportunity to poke fun at the other, more serious games it relates to.

Also returning in Borderlands 2 is the option for a cooperative multiplayer approach to playing the campaign. The multiplayer also borrows from the style made popular by games like Diablo. You are able to play with other people by either allowing them to join your session or by joining theirs. You bring your own characters and earn your own XP and loot, but the game will be progressed up to the point that the host has reached. Playing with friends, or even with random people, can make the experience exponentially more hilarious and fun.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
There were a lot of things that made Borderlands such a great game when it came out three years ago: the hardscrabble planet, the oddball characters, the hostile creatures, the diverse missions, the abundant loot, the powerful skill trees, and the novelty of all these things combined in a cooperative first-person shooter. In Borderlands 2, the novelty is gone, but all of the other elements are back and better than ever. This sequel doubles down on the successes of the original and shores up its shortcomings, improving the familiar formula and delivering dozens and dozens of hours of immensely entertaining gameplay.

THE GOOD:
- A ton of great mission writing and dialogue
- Enticing loot and experience rewards
- Intriguing skill trees
- Rich, inviting gameworld

THE BAD:
- Spoken messages sometimes interrupt each other

reviewText:
Borderlands is an FPS+RPG game that includes tons of shooting and looting fun.

Probably one of my favorite games of all time, I've had so much fun both in singleplayer and with other friends. The game has lots and lots of dlcs for you to enjoy, not to mention all the different guns this game has. It has such a massive variation  , almost every gun spawn with random parts from each manufacturer which makes it even more interesting. The art style is cartoon-ish which i think is absolutely great makes it really cool to play.

The game has alot of replay value since they give you already 4 characters with their own uniqe skills to play around with plus the two dlc characters. The game is fairly long and there is still alot of stuff to do if you actualy complete it. The world is completely open and there is alot of exploring to do in the game. I've spent up to many hours getting just one gun that i wanted, but when you finally get the gun you have been farming or hunting for you really feel that you have achieved something.

I made alot of friends in the past playing this game, either i joined random games or i found someone through the community, we had tons of fun together and we always kept on playing it every day. The coop has space for up to 4 players which i think is just fine considering the balancing of enemies (The more players you harder the game becomes, the better loot you will get.) That's really all i have to say about this wonderful game, I give it 10/10 probably the best game I've ever played, recommended to the highest.

reviewText:
My favourite thing about this game is it’s captivating story. With a lot of humour, this game pulls off an action shooter with RPG aspects and a storyline you should follow. There are lots of sidequests that will take hours to complete, but the benefits of completing this game are well worth the time. With millions of different guns, a lot of different character skins and a unique experience with all the various classes, this game has hours of fun built straight in.

The game will be fun no matter which class you play, but that’s not entirely due to the class. I found that most of the classes really lack something to keep you interested in, and throughout the whole game it feels like more attention was given to certain classes over others. Story-wise, the siren is pretty much the only class that gets any attention and backstory, as an individual with a history and as a class with abilities. All of the classes have a slight amount of backstory that becomes obvious throughout the game, but Siren has significantly more, and even then it’s very little.

Beyond that, the entertainment value of playing as certain classes over others was very noticeable to me. I played as all the classes, including the 2 DLC classes, and some of the abilities and skill trees and other class-specific aspects were lacking for a bunch of the classes. Some things that were common for all of the classes were that there are certain skill trees that seem obviously better than other ones and significantly simpler to think about, making them seem more attractive, and all of the classes lack enough in-game backstory to really get a feel for them. With all these classes, it comes down to a matter of opinion, what sort of playstyle you like and other such things, but I’ve found that there are some that are distinctly more enjoyable than others.

I think if there were more random Echo Recorders placed around the maps with a bunch of stories about the characters, with more information on them the game could be a lot more interesting. Throughout my playing of the game, I found a couple about Maya (the siren), one about Zer0 (the assassin/ghost) and nothing about any other character. That’s always been something that annoyed me. The stories of the characters may exist somewhere, but if they do, they are probably too hard to find.

In terms of story, I loved this game. There was a hint of humour in just about every interaction you had with the other characters, and the story overall was very captivating and kept me playing. I think the end-game was a bit lacking and didn’t completely match up with the story, but it was still interesting and I don’t regret playing this game through at all. The side quests in this game were very extensive, and easily one of my favourite aspects of the game. Some sidequests are very tedious and boring, but others are absolutely a blast, like those given to you by Tiny Tina (pun intended ;) ).

The replayability of this game isn’t infinite, it does get boring to play through the same parts over and over again in this game, but that doesn’t mean you can’t play it more than once at all. Replaying the game in True Vault Hunter Mode, a difficulty increase that allows you to replay the game using your already powerful character, can still be quite fun. The difficulty of the game overall becomes harder while maintaining the same story with no new additions aside from more powerful guns.

The playstyle in this game is very different from that of most other shooters. In Borderlands, you don’t really need to conserve any ammo and you can run around, jump and do a bunch of other crazy things while still attacking enemies. This makes the game more casual and relaxed, which I found to be pretty enjoyable. You very rarely run out of ammo, with all the excessive boxes with tons of different types of ammunition and the cheap price at which you can buy ammo in shops.

That brings me to my next point, which is the excess of money in this game. There is very rarely an opportunity where spending money makes much sense or is beneficial, with ammo being really cheap and not really affecting your money and most of the items in shops being pretty bad compared to the ones you can get outside from drops. I know a lot of people enjoy using the slot machines at Moxxi’s bar, but I never found it that entertaining when it for the most part doesn’t get me anything decent. Pretty much the only point of collecting money is to get the badass ranks.

The whole badass system is something I really like in Borderlands. Being able to slightly upgrade your character in about every way imaginable pretty awesome. Slowly, you’ll amass badass ranks by completing these missions, the more difficult missions resulting in more badass ranks, and for every 25 badass ranks you’ll get 1 badass token which can be used to upgrade one of the 5 stats presented. I really like the additional content that this adds to the game.

Personally, I far prefer playing this game with other people. I don’t like playing very many games alone, and even if I’m playing a singleplayer game, I like to be talking to other people at the same time. I find it a lot more enjoyable, and the same thing applies to this game. I’ve never played this game without other people simply because every moment allows for a lot more laughing and interaction when you’re doing it with other people. If I had played through this game alone, I might have noticed some interesting bits of humour, but I never would have started laughing hysterically at some glitchy motion or funny joke. The enjoyment is multiplied by a lot when playing this game with other people.

Something I noticed is that everyone plays this game differently. Personally, I like to play it patiently, doing all the sidequests, and being sure I’m making the right decisions with my skill points and gun choices. When I play Borderlands, I also like to play for as long of a period as possible. Of course I know nothing is that big of a deal, but I like being patient with this game and spending time on everything because I like feeling that I’m making the right decisions. Some of the people I have played with like to speed through the game and skip any extra content and make the easiest decisions possible. I think it’s important to play with people that have at least a similar mindset to you so that you aren’t being forced to play in a way that you aren’t entirely comfortable with.

Warning: Slight spoilers in following paragraph. Reader discretion is advised.
The final boss of the game really irked me. There was a whole obsession with how it was summoned using a siren and the key, both of which are very eridium oriented. The final boss used a lot of fiery attacks and swam in the pools of lava that surrounded the boss fight. I think it would have made a lot more sense if they were pools of molten eridium or something, with the boss spewing out eridium, or at least something purple, rather than fire.

This game also has some really amazing individual lines. They are scared all throughout the game, but easily my favourite is the line that Scooter says when you meet him in Sanctuary. I’ve probably ruined the rewatching of that line several times when replaying the game with friends, through my inability to repeat the line properly and because I keep on trying.

Overall, this game can easily be worth $20 depending on how much you play it and how much you enjoy it. I’d recommend getting it on sale simply because I’ve seen it go on sale reasonably often, for at least 66% off, but the game is also getting older and the Pre-Sequel (another game in this series, taking place between the first and second games) did come out recently. Quite simply, I love the amount of humour in this game, it’s a fun game to sink plenty of time into, and probably one of my top 10 all time games because of how much of a blast I had with it.

reviewText:
TL:DR? See CONCLUSION

INTRODUCTION:
Borderlands 2 is the sequel to the popular first-person co-op action adventure game Borderlands. Developed by Gearbox Software and published by 2K games, it uses the formula which made the first game good and expanded it in astronomical proportions. The game promises larger maps, expanded co-op play, new classes and most importantly, procedurally generated items resulting in an almost infinite weapon & item variation.

The story picks up after the events of the first game. Hyperion Corporation headed by Handsome Jack has arrived on Pandora, stolen the Vault Key and is driving the inhabitants to near extinction. The Vault Hunters from the first game (Roland, Lilith, Mordecai, & Brick) has gathered what was left of the Crimson Lance and reorganized them into the Crimson Raiders to stop Handsome Jack. The player takes control of a new set of Vault Hunters in their quest to help the Crimson Raiders stop Hyperion from opening a second Vault and unleashing a sleeping monster within.

PROS:
+ Cell-shaded textures that works well with the art style of the game
+ Great voice acting and characters, most notably, Handsome Jack
+  Expanded world which is almost 3 times larger than the first game
+ New classes with new skills that are fun to play
+ Entering and inviting for Co-op play is simple and easy
+ Improved story from the first game with well paced missions
+ Re-playability. The fun does not end after the final boss! There are new unlockable modes and expanded  adventure with...
+ Quality Story DLC that adds several hours of game time per DLC campaign
+ A lot of guns. “87 Bazillion Guns” as claimed by Gearbox
+ Improved enemy AI that goes well with...
+ Enemy Variety. Fight of bandits, robots, worms, armoured spiders, flying monsters and a whole lot more, each requiring the player to adapt by changing play-styles.
+ Substantial amount of unlockable Character customization
+ Good use of Physx for the benefit of PC gamers

CONS:
- Texture pop-in. Mostly noticeable when entering the game or entering a new area
- Loot sharing needs to be improved since ninja looting is a concern for most players
- In-game voices and messages, even story related ones, can overlap each other. New messages will cancel out any playing messages which is very annoying if your trying to immerse yourself in the story.
- No ECHO (in-game voice message) replay like the first game. Once a voice-over message given by an NPC is overlapped, there is no way to listen to it again, aside from starting a new game plus.
- Some DLC maps have glitches

CONCLUSION:
GREAT GAME and with a good blend of first-person shooting action, coupled with the progression and quest system of an RPG and all the fun and excitement of co-op play. The game expands the world with new classes, new interesting and scenic locations, weapon types, enemy variants and customization. Re-playability is massive due to the unlockable game modes and multiple high quality Story driven DLC. This game can be enjoyed by both Singleplayer or Multiplayer oriented gamers alike due to a well paced story and a very charming Antagonist.

I RECOMMEND this game to anyone looking for a fun coop experience with their buddies or story oriented gamers who likes an immersive experience. Although the game is well worth it's full price, I would still recommend this to be bought on SALE because of how often this title get discounted.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:

http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

reviewText:
Bout time I reviewed this game. This review is coming from over 2000 hours of game time (Steam and xbox combined) so i know the ins and outs of nearly every part of the game.

To start with, its a great solid game in which will provide plenty of entertainment for you and friends, solo or in a full team of 4. Yes the game is a blast solo, though alot is said about its co-op experience however that doesn't mean it isn't fun for single players, but obviously you can get more (or less in terms of loot) from playing with friends. This game is addicting, you just want more and better loot and to level up, kill the raid to get loot to kill the raid again, run arenas, play slots, chest farm, boss farm, toilet farm... well those aren't that lucrative. The fast paced gameplay and tense combat is great fun and when you get through without dying or going down you get a real sense of achievment, or relief if you did happen to do down or die. A first playthrough is always a blast and that alone is worth its cost, then if you REALLY enjoyed yourself you get to do it at a higher level, with more challenge, but more reward.

This game for me is about gameplay, not the story telling, yeah there is a stronger story than BL1 and more narrated side missions it still isn't up there with the likes of halo, GoW or other top, story focused games. So don't go in expecting to have a brilliant campaign story, go in expecting to have fun, and to have a good laugh.

There are plenty styles of play that Borderlands supports. Like being the center of attention, taking fire, tank it all and kicking out lots of dps at close range? Gunzerker. Like sitting back and sniping? Zer0, who isn't affraid to go ninja and stab enemies in the back. There is the siren, a support character for that team player. Then there's Axton, well, axton is a tricky one, tough to play at the top levels however early game, he shines with his huge tank, area of effect (the nuclear kind) and crowd control. then there are two bonus to provide lots more hours of fun after you get bored of the other four.

Yeah the game has its downs, its buggy, the scaling of certain skills, mechanics such as damage over time and certain types weapons just lose out to level. At top end level the game almost becomes unfair to the player forcing them to use only the best gear in the game, specific builds and so on, but then again, it is the top level. Its easy to break certain parts of missions forcing you to reload your game which can be very fustrating, also the AI has some weird quirks but overall isn't too game breaking.

Overall this is a game I would recommend even now just before the pre sequel as this is a game that will never grow old, will allways be fun to pick up and play, yes it has some flaws but to a flawless game is nearly impossible and well this is a game that triggered the looter shooter genre and so it must be good!

reviewText:
I found my first ever review to be a travesty to an epic game, so here is my redux :)
A combination of first person shooter and role playing game, Borderlands 2 is an addictive mix of genres that will suck away thousands of hours of your time. The cell shading art style is different - but beautiful - and can be removed with a minor tweak in the config files if you want to take it off for a small increase in performance. Removing the cell shading does not detract from the beauty of the game, just changing it slightly.

The storyline, voice work, and pace of the game are all fantastic. And I loved the humour and subtle (and some not so subtle) jokes throughout. Not much else can be said about it without giving too much away.

I would highly recommend purchasing the Game Of The Year edition and playing through the game as each of the characters to explore the differing fight mechanics that come with them. Go in guns blazing as a Gunzerker, or sneak in as an Assassin; the choice is yours. There are a few more characters and others ways to deal with enemies, and those methods will keep you busy for a long time in this game as you explore the world anew each time.

Although many of the side quests are not mandatory, they are recommended to be completed to gain experience to be able to progress through the story missions without having to empty hundreds of rounds of ammo into enemies. If you try to run through the story as fast as possible, you will find yourself coming across enemies many levels above your own, and you will die, a lot.

If you like first person shooters, you'll like this game. If you like 4 player co-op with friends, you'll like this game. And if you want a game that provides a lot of content that is good value for money, you'll like this game (GOTY Edition, anyway).

Borderlands 2 is one heck of a game.

reviewText:
-Borderlands 2-

Very good game, nice story, interesting charachers. Has a lot of replay value. It has a lot of different locations to visit, many quests to do. While playing the game you are constantly improving your character, I have all 6 playable characters on max. level (I did it for me, I was good at it) The memories with this game and playing with friends are one of the best moments. Even when you finish the main game, there are a lot of DLC's, each different and special in their own way.
Definitely recommended!

DLC1 - Captain Scarlett and Her Pirate's Booty -
It was very well done, but my favorite part was the treasure room glitch :D

DLC2 - Mr. Torgue's Campaign of Carnage -
This is the best one they made for Borderlands 2

DLC3 - Sir Hammerlock’s Big Game Hunt -
Had potential, but it turned out to be somewhat boring.

DLC4 - Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep -
It's overrated, but still fun.

UVHM - Level Upgrade from 50 to 61
This made a lot of loot obsolete, but still playable.

Digistruct Peak Challenge - Level Upgrade from 61 to 72 (and OP1-8)
This made pretty much everyone use the same builds and the same loot.

Headhunter Packs - Should've been a 5th DLC instead of 5 small packs.

reviewText: I went into the Borderlands series with this game and not knowing anything about it really.  I decided to start my experience and somewhere between that moment and the multitute of hours played non stop that preceeded, I had discovered something special indeed. Everything about it sucked me in; the creative art direction, the addicting grind in search of rare loot, and the insane characters that are voiced acted to perfection. The soundtrack plays a major role in this game's success, perfectly lending itself to the atmopshere, as well as some remarkable minimalistic songs used in towns (almost reminiscent of idling in Tristram in Diablo).  It also has something else up its sleeve, something that only comes about every decade or so; the feeling that a definitive classic has been forged, in a modern generation flooded with regurgitated cliches.  Borderlands 2 clevarly adapts gameplay mechanics from tried and true classics such as Diablo and Diablo 2, yet, has been able to produce something entirely unique, a game of the highesty quality and replayablity.\n\nBorderlands 2. Time will remember you.

reviewText:
9! 24! 58! 100! 500! 1000! Critical! Is there a better visual barometer for satisfaction in videogames than damage numbers popping out of an enemy’s bullet-riddled head? The original Borderlands revelled in this instant gratification, complementing this core conceit with a ‘bazillion’ guns, tight shooting, addictive loot and a droll sense of humour. There’s little wonder why it was such a surprise hit back in 2009, and just as unsurprising that we’re back on the bombastic world of Pandora for Borderlands 2; a sequel that once again basks in the glow of numbers and bullets, hidden treasures and boner jokes.

Set five years after the events of the first game, Borderlands 2 features an entirely new cast of playable vault hunters. After the original group opened the fabled vault and dealt with what was hidden therein, an arrogant prick by the name of Handsome Jack took credit for their actions, declared himself the dictator of Pandora, and is now attempting to plunder the planet of its most valuable resources, hoping to awaken some sort of ancient alien power. You’ll team up with a resistance movement led by the original cast of vault hunters, intent on stopping him and looting the entire planet along the way.

Those same original vault hunters also now have dialogue, fleshing them out as actual characters after their previous stint as mostly silent protagonists. Borderlands 2 presumes you have some sort of reverence for the original cast despite their previous silence, but their inclusion and subsequent portrayals pay off in some interesting ways, both in regards to the narrative and the game’s humour. Most of the dialogue is fairly sharp across the board and its multitude of zany characters, new and old. The first game’s wacky sense of humour remains, with continuous pop culture references and a ludicrous amount of hidden Easter eggs, and this carries into some of the quest design and its inherent physical comedy.

The humour’s in-your-face nature can be a little much at times, especially when jokes miss or drag on for far too long, but the near constant stream of dialogue keeps Pandora feeling alive, especially in the once-lonely single player. It can be immature at times, relying on cheap gags to generate a chuckle, but there’s also a lot of humorous dialogue that will consistently muster more than a laugh or two, and the majority of its voice acting sells each character with aplomb, delivering some fantastic performances.

The most substantial improvements come in the gameplay and how you’re able to spec your character. In the first game you could pick the Soldier class, for instance, and by the end of the game you were essentially invincible if you spec’d in the right directions. Your deployable turret could not only lay waste to everything in sight but could also regenerate health and ammunition, leaving you free to stand still and eradicate an entire group of enemies with relative ease. Borderlands 2 has been reworked and is much more balanced, giving each character class a specific playstyle that comes with their action skill and making sure to never overpower them to tedium.

There are three skill paths to choose from, each one focusing on specific areas, whether it’s improving your action skill, allowing you to do higher damage with certain weapon types, increasing your maximum health and so on. The Assassin, for example, is very similar to the Hunter class from the first game, focusing on sniper rifles and improving their effectiveness. But each class plays much differently in Borderlands 2, so the Assassin’s action skill is comparable to the Siren’s previous phasewalk ability, allowing him to turn invisible for a brief amount of time where he can utilise his melee attacks; something the Berserker class focused on in the first game.

The gun manufacturers now produce particular kinds of weapons with their own distinct visual characteristics. One such manufacturer is Jakobs, who build Wild West style guns so you’ll find lots of revolvers and rifles that can fire as fast as you can pull the trigger but reload very slowly. Maliwan, on the other hand, builds weapons that deal out elemental damage, so they’re your go to guys if you want to set someone on fire.

Whichever concoction of assorted weaponry you choose, Borderlands 2’s gunplay is tight and intuitive. Whether it’s popping the heads off bandits, melting a robot down with corrosive ammunition or hitting a Skag with the butt of your rifle, the combat remains entertaining long past your first playthrough and into new game+. This is thanks in no small part to improvements made to enemy AI.

In Borderlands 2, enemies now move with more purpose and dexterity, keeping you on your toes and forcing you to adjust your aim as they dodge and roll, duck and weave. It’s not a massive enhancement in artificial intelligence, but it’s an improvement that gives the combat a more frenetic pace. Suicidal psychos will often charge you, explosives at the ready, while various projectiles are thrown in your direction. You’re constantly dashing from place to place and there’s a fantastic freedom of movement.

There’s a phenomenal agglomeration of enemies, each befitting of some sublime character design and enjoyable AI. You’ll face off against cloaked monsters, robots that can transform into makeshift tanks and a gargantuan bandit that bursts into a fit of rage, killing friend and foe alike. Each enemy requires a different tactic to beat, whether it’s utilising your action skill, equipping a weapon with a particular type of elemental damage or inciting enemy v enemy combat.

The game looks sublime on PC as well, particularly if you can run it on close to the highest settings. The cel-shaded art style never fails to shine and there’s some outstanding lighting effects that complement the level design. This is still the same Pandora as the first game but it’s been injected with a burst of colour and environmental variety. The desert wasteland still remains but now there are plains of green grass, snow swept icy caverns and a deep underground mine coated in luminous green acid. The colour pops with the art style like a comic book; Pandora’s exalted sense of place and character still remains.

Borderlands 2 successfully maintains every aspect that made the first game such a surprise hit and improves upon them in all the ways that matter. The majority of these improvements may only be incremental which gives the impression Gearbox took the safe route, avoiding major iteration, but the formula still works. Whether that formula still appeals to you is the real question. If you’ve already spent countless hours with the first game is more Borderlands something you want? If it is then Borderlands 2 is a better game than its predecessor in every way. Just only by a smidgen.

reviewText:
All of my reviews are based around my personnal opinion, they're not swayed by a majority of people liking or disliking it.

Better than  Destiny [www.destinythegame.com]

Worse than  Borderlands 1

NOTE:
All of my reviews are laid out in a particular format that fits the game.

TL:DR
Borderlands 2 was quite an experience. It has everything. Guns, enemies, story, badassness, psychos, annoying robots. Borderlands is one of those games that you don't play for just a couple of hours. If you have friends you can play this game with, the game has become twice as more fun. With beautiful locations, an amazing story and hilarious characters this is an absolute must recommend! Buy it already!

About
Borderlands 2 is a first-person shooter RPG where you choose one of four characters, (six if you have the dlcs) and start through an epic journey. The game is set on a planet called Pandora, which is inhabited by bandits. You may notice in the trailer, there are a lot of guns. All unique in their own way. You can have a gun that shoots fire, you can have a gun that electrifies people e.t.c. Borderlands 2 is one of those story rich games that is even better with other people. A successor to the original, with added detail, more characters, and whole new locations ranging from freezing ice plains, to deserts, and even to countrysides, Borderlands, even with death everywhere, has a beauty to it.

Gameplay
It's a first-person shooter, gameplay is going to be the main part in it. This game is filled with action almost all the time. There are dozens of types of enemies which can harm you in different ways. The game may make you rely on different types of weapons. For example, an armoured enemy will take more damage from a corrosive weapon, an enemy with a shield will take more damage from an electric weapon, or an enemy with no defense would take even more damage from an incendiary weapon. This can be awkward if you don't have those weapons. As I mentioned before, this game is amazing if you have friends playing it with you. The more people in a game with you, the harder the enemies, but also the better the loot. Go through an epic journey exploring the wilds, completing side quests and complain about who gets what weapon. Then there's the dlcs....

Story
Note that I'm not going to spoil the story at all in this. Only the basis of it.
One of the best stories I've ever seen in a video game. It has exciting, dramatic parts, to emotional and sad parts. Borderlands 2 always keeps you on your toes. The story is set on a planet called Pandora, which has an uninvited guest, a company called Hyperion. The leader, Handsome Jack, wants to mine a mysterious alien element called eridium, to open a ruin on Pandora called, The Vault. You, and/or your friends are tasked with saving the planet, and defeating Handsome Jack. As well as a main story, there are also side quests, which contain their own stories within them. There are hundreds of side quests in the game for you to explore, and if need be, build XP on to level up.


Design & Graphics
Borderlands 2, as you can see by the screenshots, is a very cartoonish game, but not in the way you might imagine it. Although cartoonish, It's actually beautiful. Some environments leave you stunned. Graphics can be adjusted in the settings to make the game look even more pretty. If you don't have a perfect PC, this game can lag quite a lot, and the FPS can go down really low. Again, for the design, It's sublime. Almost everything is detailed. Open wildernesses are detailed quite well. The only negative thing I'll mention is mushy backdrops in some places.

UI [User Interface]
The Ui is rather basic to be quite honest. You have a basic hud in-game which shows your health, your shield, your ammo, your ability and a minimap. When you press the tab button, you open up a new menu which manages your inventory, your skill tree, your quests, your map and your challenges. You shouldn't have any problem navigating where to go. The game gives you basic tutorials on where everything is anyway. The main menu is also rather basic. Settings are easy to navigate. Had no problems here, neither should anyone else.

Pros - An amazing story
- Hilarious characters
- Beautiful environments
- Great soundtrack
- Worth plenty of hours of playtime
- Entertaining co-op
- Great replay value
- So many guns!!!!
- Epic DLCs

Cons - Inventory space can be a pain.
- Sometimes relying on co-op too much.
- Sometimes bland backdrops.
- Some PCs may struggle when it comes to FPS.

Final Recommendation
Borderlands 2 is an almost perfect game, which is worth hundreds of hours of playtime. Whether it be alone or with friends, this game is addicting as hell. I'm still not bored of it and I doubt I will be for a long time. Finishing the game may seem like you've done a lot, but then you hae the dlcs to finish, which will give you even more guns, and even more fun!!! A must play for anyone, even if it's not on sale!

Final Verdict - 10/10.

reviewText:
Its hard to said bad things about Borderlands 2 since it almost flawless.
This is the perfect game for you and your friends to play with.
Let me run down a few pros and cons for you to decided if it worth your money or not.
PROS:
+ Great Story with a lot of Humors and style in it.
+ Great Co-op mode to keep you playing with friends.
+ FPS game with RPG element in it.
+ Each main NPC has there own styles of talking.
+ Guns with additional elements and rarity to keep you spending in game money for that Jackpot.
+ Lots of DLC to keep you busy.
+ Unique visuals with cel-shaded style.

CONS:
- Some class seem to be OP (Gunzerker)
- Legendary Weapon are hard to find even rare.
- No Multiplayer pvp which is find for me but some ppl might don't
- Over world have no boundaries so I fall into ocean and wasted my time to get back.
- Invisible walls in some areas(usually when you climbing)

Overall: 8.5/10 - Fantastic Fps story telling game.

reviewText:
Want bazillions of guns? Wanna play as a cyborg ninja assassin? Wanna shoot the heads off of lunatics and murderers? If you answered yes to any of the above, then this game is for you.
If you didn't, but you're still interested, don't worry, this game has a lot more. The battles can be epic as hell, the customization is great, and the music is amazing.
Tons of quests to keep you going, tons of guns to experiment with, and a great story to play through with lots of good, crude humor, and tons of easter eggs to find. And don't get me started on the wacky Tiny Tina.
This game is loads of fun and If you loved the first one, you're going to LOVE this one too. And the best part is, There is no crawmerax!! (At least not in the base game)

It's like fallout on psycho!

9.5/10

reviewText:
Big. Brilliant, Funny. Visually Beautiful. Borderlands 2 is near perfect.

The level design is inspired. The story is great, and the voice work is great. You have to listen to the various things the bandits say when you are fighting them. They often die with a funny one-liner.

It's a run and gun with LOTS of guns, much like the first Borderlands, only MORE polished and with deeper levels of writing. I can't see where the dreary I'm so serious" 4 and 5 review scores are coming from. We are talking about VIDEO games. This one has a fine balance between instant fun and long term 'purpose'.

There are a few minor mechanics that could be improved. The player character could certainly benefit from a jet pack or another way to get around faster! Bigger levels and easier access to the structures through a climbing mechanic would be nice. Otherwise great work Gearbox.

I like it so much I just went and bought ALL the DLC at full price
date: to be sure the developers get a taste of my money! They deserve it for making one of the most entertaining and lighthearted gun romps out there tight now.\n"

reviewText:
loot and shoot.

Buy advice: [Borderlands 2 GOTY edition + Ultimate Vault Hunter Upgrade Pack 2] buy these two during a steam sale is the best advice I can give for anyone. It'll run you right now about $15-$18 and you'll have all the DLC's worth having without rebuying or spending a bunch of money. It gets asked constantly in the forums.

Classic FPS that can have a high entertaintement/hour value with replayable storylines, scaleable enemies, with better and better loot as you go. There are three main types of BL2 players I've seen. You have the diehard, the casual, and the barely interested. The diehards love doing the playthroughs, they love farming bosses and loot, they love the skills; they are great players and they have above 1k hours in the game, they can talk shop about this game all day but they're a dying breed because the game does have a half life for how interesting it is; the diehards will buy the game when it comes out, they don't need a steam sale, they'll buy all the DLCs and they bought TPS (the pre-sequel) for $60 the day it came out and already have 50 hours on it. The barely interested will wait for the steam sale, they'll wait for a few friends and they'll play up to level 30, maybe 60, they'll buy only the GOTY version, and theyll have 40 hours and be done with it. The hard part is figuring out if you're a casual player since you've never played the game.

The best way for a casual player to play is to select the most interesting character to you (first time favorites: commando, siren, assassin) and you play them through until you finish all the storylines, challenges, achievements, sidemission and do level 1 to 72 to op8, that will take about 200-300 hours. Then you normally don't want to do another complete playtrhough of a couple hundred hours so you get powerleveled through to op8 on the other characters and you can go through the storylines easier, you can play with the skills and see how the skills work and even more fun see how the skills work with all the loot, most likely duped loot. Most of your playtime then will be helping others get there missions done, doing raid bosses, a little farming and the game will reach its half life, that will take another few hundred hours and you'll be finished with the game.

reviewText:
I can very easily say that this is the finest game that I have ever played.  Borderlands 2 is an improvement (for the better) in nearly every aspect of the original game.  Borderlands 2 comes with a much better story, much more varied environments and enemies, better user interface and more variety in the way the gear behaves.

The cooperative system is also very much improved in Borderlands 2.  The game moved away from using Gamespy for an online lobby and now uses full Steam integration with drop-in and out cooperative play.

The game features 4 new classes (Soldier, Siren, Gunzerker and Assassin) with 2 others available for purchase via DLC (Mechromancer and Psycho).  Each class features all-new skill trees that have been mostly well designed and appear to work well for both solo and team play.

Most of the original cast of NPC characters have returned along with a few new ones.  The story is very well written this time with an extremely interesting villain in Handsom Jack.  The story for Borderlands 2 does attempt to be a continuation of the original game and miraculously improves the previously lackluster story to a point where it now actually makes some sense.  The game also includes a TON of sidequests and activities so you can expect to have about 30 hours of gameplay with the main questline and roughly 50+ hours if you include most of the side activities.  There are 4 large campaign DLC and a variety of smaller DLC packs which will add significantly to an already huge amount of content.

The only few negative things that I have found in the game include:
1)  Less storage space than you had in the original game.
2)  Inability to replay echo logs like you could in the original.
3)  There is much more dialog (good) but too easy to interrupt (bad) with no way to replay as mentioned in my second point above.

Overall I feel that Borderlands 2 is a huge improvement over the original in most aspects and the many improvements definitely outweigh the few negatives.  I have newer games in my library but this one always keeps drawing me back.

reviewText: My experience with Borderlands 2 started off very negative. I thought it was a slow paced and quite boring game. This all changed as I pushed myself to continue playing. The quests are entertaining and suprisingly replayable, the variety of characters beckoned me to try out their very different play styles and powers, and the feeling of getting a better item than your current one never gets old. The DLC is worth the money and gives you new environments that are different to the vanilla games offerings. It is also a very good game with friends, especially with 4 different classes. Overall, I am very much enjoying my time with this game, and as long as you can get past the first levels with your first character, you will have a blast. 9/10, must buy.

reviewText:
Wow... I think I'm in love with the Borderlands universe.

There's just something really special about this game: the way the characters grow on you, the explosive atmosphere, the compelling story, the weird but incredible way they weave heavy moments and introspection in a game filled to the brim with humor, gore and internet memes. I feel like this game is the best it can get, or at least until Gearbox or some other developer comes up with something even better. With such a diverse cast of characters, I find it hard to imagine NOT being able to relate to at least one of them despite how extreme their personalities can be. It's not all haphazard extremeness either and each is endearing in their own way. The game is very inclusive of queer characters and neurodivergent characters. They follow stereotypes, they break stereotypes, and their differences are natural and introduced as such. Handsome Jack is on par with Pagan Min as my favorite antagonist. Every character feels alive and has defining dialogue and the areas you can explore are often beautiful. Pandora is a harsh yet vibrant world that you will blast through over and over until you finally come out on top. The FPS genre generally isn't very memorable but here's a game that smashes the rules and brings out its own style.

Gunplay is the heart of Borderlands and there is a huge number of quests you can complete to gain better guns, loot and experience. I found levelling and looting enjoyable and the skill trees are decent but slightly underwhelming as a lot of them become useless if you grind to endgame difficulty modes. It goes without saying... there's a lot of grinding in this game and a couple fetch" sidequests. Especially early on when you're stuck with some really low level equipment. But once you get past that initial slow start
date: the game really picks up and you'll find yourself shooting electricity out of shotguns and facing more challenging opponents with better rewards. I think the only gripe I might have with the gameplay is that some bosses felt poorly designed-- sort of same-y with almost all of them having unavoidable area-of-effect attacks. Until recently the drop rates for legendaries was notoriously difficult but has been fixed. Minor bugs exist but with the rest of the game being completely incredible I found them more funny than annoying.\n\nThere are four playable characters (plus two more in GOTY edition) that each have their own perks and quotes. No matter who you choose you'll have a good time while they rattle off at enemies or make it to second wind just in time. There's Axton

hoursPlayed: who makes a great tank and support. Maya

So, I don't usually write review for games but I'll make an exception for this one:

Pros:

Cons:

Overall, the game is amazing and it's worth buying it. The most bad thing that will happen to you is to have a few hours of fun. But make sure to have your friends with you cause Pandora is a dangerous place. Welcome Vault Hunters to your doom.

reviewText:

You are a Vault hunter, and you seek for quests and victory!

The storyline is very rich and interesting. Personally for me it wasn't easy to understand it. Its kinda complicated, but the game is fun. Its fun that you can play online with your friends or random people. In a lobby you can invite 3 more people. 4 people in one lobby is max.
Borderlands 2 is better than any game from borderlands franchise. It has been proven by gamers that played borderlands series.

+Rich storyline

CONS:

reviewText:
9.5/10 - Amazing CoOp FPS; Improves On Original

I loved the first installment of Borderlands, but this second offering improves on that template in almost every way! You have brilliant, unique graphics, plenty of FPS action and elements of RPG and tons of Loot!

The best thing about this game is the CoOp online. I haven't even played much solo on the PC and probably won't since this element is so fun! You can play with 3 other friends through the entire lengthy campaign; that's good because I definately need the help. Although the game is 4 years old I never have to wait more than a minute to find a team to play with!

Worth the $20; a high replay value especially with Coop Features.

reviewText:
Geeky pop culture references, comical quips, badass and dorky characters with a surprising amount of depth, sweet loot; an adventure best experienced with friends (I didn't like playing by myself). Goes on sale often and worth every penny, including DLC.

9.5/10

EDIT: Gotten quite a bit of upvotes so I'm going to give this a better review. After getting through a bit of the first Borderlands, I love this game so much more. They have made massive amounts of improvements—significantly better UI, quests complete with full voice overs, awesome references, an easy-to-read mini-map, a gorgeous vibrant world, colorful characters, no invisible walls when driving, uninterrupted sprinting, auto-vacuum ammo/health hypos, brilliant addressing of social issues (lookin' at you Torgue! <3), shared ammo & money, and intriguing storylines. Even the sidequests are interesting and they AREN'T mandatory for you to do in order to have any semblance of an equal fight with main story mobs—as it should be. Everything is bigger and better. Couldn't have asked for a greater FPS-RPG.

reviewText:
If I were to describe video games in an extremely complicated metaphor that tied in mammals, reptiles, ethnic food, and figures from mythology, Borderlands 2 would be something like a Platypus-Snake-JapaneseSesameChicken-Surma.

Platypus: Why a platypus? Because Platypuses/Platypeese/Platypii are unique. They're a weird hybrid thing that is actually pretty cool. Borderlands is practically a second cousin of the platypus, with all that uniquity. The best way I can think to explain it would be to draw up the image of an MMO. MMOs let you run around, level up, dump skill points everywhere, find loot to kill things to find more loot of varying rarity, and some of them let you enter instanced dungeon areas to kill monsters with your friends (Where applicable).
Borderlands is pretty similar to that, but it's a first person shooter. You pick a class, get killed first thing off, and then start your adventure as the semi-official minion of the incessantly talking Wheatley/Gir mashup named Claptrap(More like shut-your-trap, amirite?). Your adventure will have you killing enemies for random loot, levelling up to get different perks that let you build your own style of character, and taking side quests from NPCs. the whole game is like one of those aforementioned instanced dungeons, where you can drag up to three friends (Or, should you lack those, random people online that probably hate you just because they are the internet) and go monster slaying. I've heard that if your friend takes your loot, you can stop being friends and then challenge him to a now-unfriendly duel to kill him and take what's rightfully yours. I wouldn't know, because I don't really..... have... friends. And I hate the internet people.
In summary: Borderlands 2 is an FPSMMO but not MMO because instead of being massive multiplayer it's like 4 multiplayer, but still retains all the typical trimmigns of one of the nicer MMOs. It's like halo with quests.
After your head finishes exploding at how fun that sounds, carry on reading.

Snake: Snakes look pretty cool, and they make neat sounds.
You know what else looks cool?
I do! I have awesome curly hobbit hair like Frodo.
But I'm not the only cool-looking thing around. Cel-shaded graphics are pretty neat as well. Borderlands 2 has a really cool art style that makes it super obvious you're playing Borderlands and not something else. For the easily confused, it may be nice to be able to tell what game you're playing at a glance.
Sound-wise, it's wunderbar (German for wonderful. Also useful: Der Mann isst das Kind" means "I like children"
date: which is good to know because people trust you more if you like children). Everyone's voiced
recommended: and they voiced real nice. Guns sound like guns. Bad guys sound like bad guys and say things like "I will kill you" before making guns noises come out of their guns.\n\nJapanese Sesame Chicken: HOLY CHILDREN OF GOD SESAME CHICKEN IS GOOD. I order it every time I go to a Japanese restaurant
hoursPlayed: much in the same way I ordered Borderlands 2. fun is good

reviewText: A lot of different guns with different effects,like slaging for extra dmg, fire dmg, corrosion dmg, electricity dmg, explosion dmg and normal dmg.There are many shields with enhanced capacity or booster shields dropping shield energy items to refresh shield energy before depleted, shields with bonus dmg to melee dmg or 1 unique shield for bonus ranged dmg at full shield capacity.Spiked shields which do dmg to melee attackers and 1 unique shield to ranged attackers(homing spikes shot at).Character class items to improve skills in your skilltree and so on.a lot of different legendary items and also special items which can be purchased in special currencies, like seraph crytals gain at bosses slain on hardest difficulty(also overpowered lvl) and torque tokens collectin at torques campaign or gaining by doing a quest Bar brawl witch can be repeated infinite.If you die you turn in a fight for your life modus,where you after killing an enemy in a short time span, get back into action, otherwise you die and will be respawned at the last waypoint/travelstation, loosing an ammount of money.Travelling by car is good but using travelstations to get fast to other locations is fast and awesome. 6 classes 4regular and 2 dlc chars, 3skilltrees. 4 players coop, you can also duell each other, different looks for your characters, outfits and heads and vehicles skins, Boss enemies for 1 Insane skilled char or for 2-4 Players.Vehicles 2 different cars, in the normal game, at Hammerlocks Hunting Dlc 1 Hovercraft and 1 Boat at Scarlets Pirate Dlc. Doing quests and other tasks gives you Badass rank for some Bonuspoints, increasing gun dmg, gun accuracy or maximum Health, maximum Shields, faster reload and so on. Lvl cap is 72, if you have that Digistruck Peak Dlc, otherwise 50. Great game, but storing Stuff is a problem, shared stash a bit small 4 items, but good that there is one. The regular safe could be pimped by spending eridium bars, also the Ammunition/Grenade capacity you can handle.Funny dialogs and other stuff included. This game is made in a comic look and i like it ;) Hm, forgot to say there are golden keys available in this game to open a loot chest in sanctuary, which contains loot of your actual level. I started with 8 keys and you can find around the whole internet options to increase the number of keys to get some maybe good loot.Another Benefit from Digistruct Peak dlc is, after solving the histoty of simulated violence, you unlock overpowered lvl 1. On this difficult the complete game get a bit harder higher leveled enemies, but also better loot overpowered 1 items.After each overpowered lvl solved overpowered difficult can be raised at the main menu. The maximum overpowered lvl is 8. I played the whole game without any mods and so is the review about the game.If you want to help a friend getting overpowered lvl´s unlocked, your friend has to host the game.

reviewText:
Difficulty: Just Right
The Bottom Line: Been There, Done That/Great
Score: 8.5

I've been waiting for a game like Borderland to come out for a very long time.Lucky me,I got Borderland 2 instead of a similar game. I've been longing for a sequel ever since I played the original game back in 2009.Every sequel should be improved upon its prequel. Borderland 2 does what Borderland didn't do back at that time,and it does it better.

Everything in the game is just an improved version of the original Borderland. I was so skeptical at first. I was so excited about the game when it first came out. I wanted to try it on my new custom-built PC. The results for me, were just amazing and satisfying

Borderlands 2 story didn't make sense and had no actual plot, but if you played the original game and knew what the hell was going on. The four previous characters awakened a big-a$$ monster final boss of Borderland 1" and caused a disruption. A material called an Eridium scatters all over Pandora and becomes the currency for black market and the new big thing for research.

They finally ditched outdated GameSpy for online co-op games and integrated Steam
date: which is more than warm welcome. Despite the changes
recommended: some players still have issues with online gaming
hoursPlayed:
mostly caused by their router configuration.

Overall: Borderlands 2 is one of the best games of this year. If you've played the original then you'll instantaneously be familiar with everything and u will like this sequel better. Although I miss my Lilith/old characters but i forgot to say that im still playing borderlands 1 and it is still my favorite BL till this moment come join me BL1 honeys.

Now go buy/play Borderlands 2! You've wasted enough of your gaming time reading this review. Oh and... give a kiss to Moxxxi (p.s. don't forget to tip her."

reviewText:
I have never played the original Borderlands. I decided to play Borderlands 2 to see what this franchise is like. I first noticed the cel-shaded graphics and a diverse number of characters to choose from. After I chose my protagonist (Gunzerker) I had to get used to the skill trees, the wacky characters, the large number of side missions in addition to the main story missions. One of the wackiest characters is Claptrap, a robot with something to say all the time and is quite delusional.

The story is set in Pandora, a planet filled with vicious creatures of all kinds. The planet is control by Handsome Jack, the main antagonist of the game. As you progress through the game you will regularly hear Handsome Jack’s speak sarcastically about your goal to bring him down. There are many Echo recorders that will help flesh out the story and who Handsome Jack really is.

The script and voice acting in Borderlands 2 is nothing short of superb. The voice actors and script writers should be highly commended for making the characters such as Scooter, Moxxi, Claptrap and others very entertaining. The only problem I found with the voices was that some conversations can be interrupted by other conversations before you can hear them completely. However, it’s not such a bad thing for the game overall.

There is plenty to explore and if you’re into exploring as much as possible, Borderlands 2 will entertain you for 100+ hours. Each sector of the map has its own environmental feel and its own creatures. The DLCs add even more content for you to explore, but you are best advised to advance your character to at least level 20 because the enemies are much tougher than those enemies in the main story. The DLCs are divided into chapters and side missions while the battles with tougher creatures will reward you with lots of experience points. The side missions in the main game are definitely worth pursuing, as they include puzzle elements and some very simple goals such as simply shooting someone in the face in the side mission titled “Shoot This Guy in the Face.” Other side missions require you to find certain items to receive a unique weapon such as the side mission titled “The Lost Treasure”, a mission that requires you to find different parts of a treasure map. The parts can be anywhere in a region, but the payoff is huge in the form of a very powerful pistol.

Part of what makes Borderlands 2 great in gameplay is the diverse availability of weapons, shields, grenade mods, class mods, and relics. Class mods and relics have ways of enhancing your character’s combat abilities. The inventory feels a little clunky, but once you get used to it you can navigate it pretty quickly. The inventory is important for using in the various vending machines for buying ammo, selling ammo and streamlining.

Respawning is an integral part of this game, as enemies will respawn when you return to the same sector. It may feel tedious after a while, but it can be rewarding because these are opportunities to gain more experience as you try to reach the level of 50. To max out your character you will have to complete the normal mode in order to open up the True Vault Hunter Mode. It is important to know the strengths and weaknesses of enemies so that you know which weapons and ammo work best against them. For example, the loaders (mechanical bots) are vulnerable to corrosive ammo. Therefore, it is best to use a corrosive weapon to kill them faster. The crystallisks are hulking creatures with shins that are made of brittle crystals. Shooting their brittle shins is the only way to bring them down.

This game encourages cooperative play, so it can be fun playing with friends. However, it is better to play with friends who are at a level close to yours, although the game automatically balances the difficulty according to the levels of the players. It is a great feeling trying to heal fellow players in dire times. The unusual feature of death is interesting because there is a chance to achieve a second wind if you get a kill while you’re dying and the red meter is going down to zero.

I found the save system awkward since it saves everything that happens. If you leave the game while in the middle of a mission, you will have to pick up where you left off and the enemies you killed will respawn. In essence, the save system consists simply of save and quit.

Borderlands 2 is one of the most entertaining role-playing games with so much to explore. The gameworld is thriving with loot and opportunities to reap the rewards of doing favors for other townsfolks. I highly recommend this game to anyone as it will take many, many hours of your time and those hours will feel worth it.

reviewText:
Well it's gearboxe's baby. The hot seller, but really is there a reason why? There sure is.
Gameplay+ All just feel's finely polished.
+ Many boss-battle's to be had.
+ Looting from trash to spider's to mutant's.
+ 4 fun character's & while even more with dlc's.
+ Friendly A-i is actually good & provide's support.
+ Many side-quest's with good humour here & around.
+ Many character upgrade's such as slot,ammo,inventory increase.
+ Wide-wide-wide range in equipment from shield's to relic's to what-not.
+ Solid gunplay & good hit-box, oh my did i even say how much fun it is.
+ Many variation in enemie's type's from bandit's to nomad's & alot-more.
+ More than a thousand weapon-combination's, & all randomly generated.
+ The game provide's a fair amount of dificulty, can be mostly challenging.
+ One of the best,stylish game u-i to be had from the inventory to the map.
+ Each character with it's own special charactistic's,upgrade's and what-not.
+ All enemie's with many different basically approache's, some don't use cover like psycho's while other's do.

- Easy way to do exploit's.
- Some occasional A-i bug's.
- Some death's can really feel cheap.
- Weapon's & such aren't upgradable.
- Many colution bug's and here around.
- Many way's to farm enemie's &/or bosse's.

Story+ Great,great dialogue.
+ From funny to awesome.
+ Literraly all vilian's speak up to directly.
+ Each character has about just enough-backstory.
+ Introduction vid's for bosse's & many character's.
+ It all get's it with just well making-sense & not making sense.

NeutralControll's can collide a bit, such as if you're in a vehicle & want to go to another map you may just accidently get of the car if not facing directly as the button is same for that.

Can be a bit demanding. ( At time's )

If you only play just the main-mission's then you're gonna have a hard time beating enemie's due to the level-difference(s).

Design( Graphic's )Included+ Just all pleasing to the eye.
+ Great & stliyish and original from the menu to all.
+ All enviroment's are well-designed & with fine graphic's.
+ Character's are all well-modeled & spot on to psycho's and such.
+ Map-design is great on, many type's of different terrian map's.Desert,snow,summer to alot more.

- PhysX is broken and cause's incredible lag's.
- Some texture/shadow lod problem's &/or draw distance problem.

Sound's + OST+ All just awesome & correct.
+ Sound-track can be chilly,tense and alot more.
+ Well,well,well & great vioced character's to every villian,enemy and friendly.

- There is a radio, which is bassicaly bare-bone's.......

ConclusionIf you're looking for a just a fun,fun, & crazy shooter then this is for you. With a great-combat and gameplay,story,dialogue i see no reason not to buy it.

Oh & if you're not buying it cause of fear that you must play the first 1 to understand the story, then you're completely wrong as there's already about enough back story here.

reviewText:
Overall, the art, narration and characters are really memorable. Considering I'm not much of an FPS fan (I haven't played BL1, note that), the number of hours I've put into this game is actually something I didn't plan out or expect.

First to run through was pretty fun, and somewhere halfway around the second one (if not for the DLCs), the game start to drag a little bit on solo. I particularly liked how skills can be conveniently reset anytime along side with the large variety of weapons (gun porn~!). Trying out different builds made the game really interesting to play. I also like how some quests have quirky and funny storylines.

If you're playing with friends, it's a great game to play! At this point in time, I don't think I'll be picking up BL2 again if I weren't playing with someone else. At higher levels, raid bosses get to be more frustrating than challenging, and the cycle of running through the same thing - griding and trying to score good loot just wears me out.

I picked this game up on sale and bought it with friends, so the experience of laughing at Claptrap cursing stairs was really awesome. I would definitely say it's at least worth the money and worth playing.

reviewText: Borderlands 2\n\nBorderlands 2 is a fun game about Vault Haunters that seek for a treasure worth lots of money. That's the whole plot of this game and the rest is pure fun and comedy, now the game. The game is different from other shooters, it mixes RPG elements with first person shooters, it's preety much funny and has ridicoulous weapons. The game itself is a fun and somehow challenging way to spend time. The enemies get harder each time you progress through the game and you have to level up when you want to go on. However it isn't the perfect shooter game... This game has some flaws that could of been solved (Maybe not all of them but most of them). Some things I didn't like about the game was the fact that it can get repetitive and that at times if you want to continue and enemies are a higher level than you, you might have to grind... Which of course isn't a good thing, specially on a game with so many RPG elements. This game has a skill tree too which lets you use abilities to affect the way you battle, this feature was implemented in the first game and hasn't changed in any way. You can first level up only 3 abilities on the 3 skill trees that you have, each skill tree can give you different skills and of course like in any RPG you need skill points, you earn these by leveling up. You can also earn badass coins that will randomly level up one stat of your character. This can come in handy later on but the game doesn't show you about this feature and I discovered it while messing around in the menus. This game has alot of DLC too, each of them is fun and preety cheap compared to the ones from other games... Like most EA games but that's another topic. The season pass can get you most story DLC but still doesn't give you all of it, the way the developers still support this game via DLC is very good and I like it, if you are against DLC and you think it'll never be close to the full game expirience you are wrong. The DLC takes time to make and isn't just a golden skin weapon pack or something similar. Now let's talk about the Co-Op feature. This feature has been implemented since the first game and you can play it with 2-4 people. This is a huge help but if you aren't playing the same quest it can be tough, since each player that joins will make every enemy tougher. I recommend playing it from the start to finish with a buddy. You can try out a new character if you want but that's your choice. Something useful about Co-Op is the revive feature that can save you and your buddies alot, specially when you are going on a location with enemies that have a higher level or are just harder than usual. This game has lots of potential and I can't wait for the PS Vita version I give it a 4.5/5.

reviewText:
«У них же были дети, родители, семьи… Как ты мог? Шучу. Убей их всех!»
Да и могла ли атмосфера поменяться? События второй части разворачиваются на той же планете Пандоре всего через несколько лет после известного провала четверки охотников за Хранилищем. По пустынным равнинам все так же бегают скаги, в небе парят свободные ракки, а бандиты разбивают свои лагеря. Однако кое-что изменилось. Вскрытие героями Хранилища спровоцировало выход эридиума — сверхценного ресурса, на добычу которого направлена деятельность корпорации «Гиперион». Красавчик Джек, возглавивший «Гиперион», объявил политику очищения планеты от бандитской заразы колонистов, которые для совместного противостояния корпорации сплотились в местечке под названием Убежище. Таким образом, сюжетным фоном выступает классическая борьба могущественных, многочисленных, но «злых» эксплуататоров и слабых, но нравственно более одаренных повстанцев. В сюжетной завязке Borderlands 2 не блещет оригинальностью, повторяя каноническую схему многих антиутопических произведений. Тем не менее по ходу игры сюжет увлекает, нас ждут приятные и не очень неожиданности, которые проливают свет на события первой части.Система развития персонажа в Borderlands 2 не сильно отличается от оригинала. Уничтожая различную живность, а также выполняя задания, игрок получает опыт. Каждый новый уровень автоматически увеличивает максимальное здоровье и урон, а также дает одно очко умения, которое можно вложить в развитие того или иного навыка. У каждого из персонажей есть три специализации, представляющие собой набор тех или иных умений. Например, у убийцы Зеро это снайперское мастерство, хитрость, резня.Чтобы улучшить следующую ступень специализации, нужно вложить 5 очков в предыдущую. А таких ступеней у каждого персонажа шесть. Таким образом, чтобы дойти до вершины специализации, нужно иметь как минимум тридцатый уровень. А это значит, что можно стать или выдающимся снайпером, или крутым рубакой в ближнем бою, или всем понемногу.Что же касается боевой составляющей, то и с этой стороны игра похорошела.

Плюсы: потрясающий стиль; фирменный юмор; колоритные герои; многообразие оружия.
Минусы: система развития персонажа могла быть интересней.

reviewText:
Absolutely fantastic and thoroughly enjoyable!

++ Wonderful character designs
++ Great dialogue supported by excellent voice acting
++ Unique skill trees even for what is essentially a shooter
++ Numerous weapon and accessory varieties
++ DLCs add a huge amount of content and replayability
++ Extremely enjoyable single and co-op play
++ Pop culture references galore (add nothing to a story but are always a nice touch)

-- Repetitive mob and boss types
-- Difficulty scales up in sheer brute force rather than combat intelligence or tactics
-- Redundant kill, find, fetch, and delivery quests
-- Claptrap

Not a lot of cons for me in this game. I'm just kidding about Claptrap. He is as funny as he is annoying (most of the time).

I had the retail release of BL2 (and none of the mission packs and Vault Hunter upgrades at that time) way before I even became a Steam member. It's still as much fun now as it was back then. The DLCs add fresh content plus a good dose of hilarity, especially the Mechromancer and Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep!

In terms of play and narrative, this is a very simple game at its core, but it's incredibly fun because it does it what it does with great polish, and the presentation is top-notch.
