reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Borderlands2 is a First Person action adventure shooter game developed by Gearbox and released 2012. Borderlands2's story takes place on the planet Pandora... Pandora is a very violent war-torn planet where no one in their right mind would visit, except for the insane... being bandits, local inhabitants who can't get off world, and vault hunters.

-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: You're a vault hunter, you've been lured onto Pandora in attempts to find the mystical place known as “the vault”, in the vault you gain unimaginable treasure... should you succeed in finding the vault; there's no telling what wonders you will encounter.
But wait, before you run off and try to open the vault yourself, there are many enemies who wish to claim the vault as their own prize! Not to mention monstrous beasts that protect the vault. You don't even know where to go! To find the vault you will need friends, cue “Handsome Jack”...

...okay, okay, by now most people actually know how this story goes, the Story telling in Borderlands2 is excellent, a nice blend of cinematic, voiced dialogue.

Game Play: Borderlands2 is played in the first person view, initially there are only four playable characters/classes (with mods you gain 2 more), you have different types of weapons, elements, many different types of NPC's to fight, 3 skill tree's for each class.

The playable characters/classes are: Axton (Commando), Maya (Siren), Salvador (Gunzerker), Zero (Assassin), and with purchasing the appropriate DLC you gain access to Gaige (Mechromancer), and Krieg (Psycho). If you want to know more about a specific character/class I would recommend checking out online guides.

It's important to note that there are about 6 different classifications of weapons (Assault rifles, sniper rifles, pistols, shot guns, 'ya know – the normal gun you expect) it's even more important to note that each character/class can use any weapon... however some characters are better at certain weapons because of skill builds. (meaning, Zer0 (the sniper/assassin) is better with sniper rifles, but you can pick one up with Salvador (gunzerker) and use it, but you probably won't be as accurate as Zer0 is.

In addition to various weapons, are there many different special perks a gun can randomly roll, including different elements (Incendiary, Corrosive, Shock, and Explosive) which are more effective against different types of enemies. The point is, that the same gun can drop twice and have completely different stats.

Achievements: Borderlands2 has 69 achievements in total, 50 achievements are available on the core game, the 19 other achievements are spread out across 4 DLC items you'll need to purchase to get 100%. All of the achievements are very obtainable, however, some require some grinding and luck (like, Challenge Accepted, Tribute to a vault hunter, and a number of other circumstantial achievements) Lastly, there is at least one achievement per class, the rest can be obtained with one character.


Price: Borderlands2 is priced at $19.99 The game of the Year edition is priced at $39.99. I personally suggest purchasing the game of the year edition so you can get the DLC for the whole game. With the release of Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel the chances of picking up a copy of Borderlands2 on sale is dramatically increased, so it's worth noting that you could wait for a 75% off sale.

Conclusion: Borderlands2 is hilarious, fun, has morbid-humor, insane people, guns, guns and more guns! I have little to nothing negative that I can say about the game. The graphics for the game itself are more cartoon-styled in nature, increasing the life of the game (It won't take back seat to high end graphic games as fast, because they're trying to replicate realism, they're implementing their own style and art).
All in all, I loved playing Borderlands2, I played the heck out of the game, it's more fun to play it with a friend, but it's one of those games you can spend a lot of time playing just to blow up bandits. I recommend this game for FPS gamers, and people who enjoy Adventure/Action games.

reviewText:
Borderlands 2 is not as good as the first game. Oh, sure, it's got a better (more emotional!) story, more diverse maps, more vehicles, a cool head and skin system, more gun types and effects, and is just all around a bigger, more varied experience, but it's not... well, okay. The first game wasn't a great shooter. Borderlands 2 isn't either. It mostly relies on simply pointing and clicking. The stats all ultimately determine how quickly an enemy's health bar diminishes in size. It's not as if we're playing Half-Life or Halo or FEAR or Bulletstorm or something, because we're not. We're playing a game that's about loot.

Too bad the loot drop ratios are so bad. I don't know why they're worse than they were in the original game, but I do know that in my hundred-some hours of play, I only managed to pick up four or five orange items. That seems wrong. Borderlands 2 is the first game that made me seriously consider using CheatEngine. Me, I don't like cheats unless they're humorous, but Borderlands 2's drop ratios are so frustrating, requiring needless, endless grinding from players, that I found myself kinda going yeah... let's make things more like they were in the first game."

The story is great. I've mentioned that. I should mention it again. It's great. Best of all is Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep

reviewText:
Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam group
Few words about the game
Personally it's my most favourite universe in whole... universe, yeah that makes sense. What can I say about the game, you're playing as a Vault Hunter, running around Pandora, which is planet where basically every living creature wants you dead. Great combination of first person shooter with roleplaying game. It can't get repetetive with over a gazillion of weapons and shields you can find.

Advantages
Great story, dialogues, epic backstory of every single character
Awesome sense of humor fullfils whole story perfectly
Graphics are original and stylish, unique map design can be seen everywhere
Long, differential gameplay full of boss battles and hundreads of enemy types
4 players coop, one of the best designed of all games
Perfectly selected soundtrack and ideally voiced characters
Moxxi ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)
Disadvantages
Easy to exploit many aspects of game
From time to time there are problems with loading textures / shadows / long distances even with good setup
Disappointing in-game radio, i was hoping for more awesome songs to listen
There is kind of need" to do side quests as You will have troubles to beat monsters / bosses due to level differences if You will go on fully by story missions
If you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!"

Campaign/story-wise the game continues the series acceptably but it feels somewhat repetitious.

reviewText:
Borderlands 2... hmm... well, assuming you've never heard of this AAA title. that means you're either Obsessed with one game (likely Call of Duty, that one Zombifies many) or you've had the extreme misfortune of being afflicted by one of the following:
1. You could be blind, in which case I do not recommend this game.
2. You could be deaf, read #1 and please read it to a blind friend.
3. You have had a sheltered gaming career.

If you are any of the above, I can only tell you this; Try out the game if you like doing Role Playing Games and Shooters.

If you are not one of the listed, how do you not know about this game. Whatevs.
The game has a great story line (you should play #1 first if story is your thing)
Has engaging music.
Engaging gameplay.
Comedy, genuinely fun to play, listen to, watch, observe the world of the game around you.
Randomized weapons.
Loot, stats, rares, legendaries, the whole 9 yards of RPGs.
100s of hours of gameplay (like honestly)
Co-Op Multiplayer of up to 4 players
Dueling, trading etc
Worthwhile DLCs (personally recommend GOTY version)
Great community

and what else.... hmm... Great graphics etc. look it's a AAA title for a few reasons.


Story: 10/10 (Perfect, original)
Gameplay: 10/10 (Levels are challenging and skill based and near infinite.)
Presentation: 10/10
Soundtrack: 9/10 (nothing really FANTASTIC, but great.)
Replayability: 7/10 (Co-Op, DLCs, Completion)

Campaign DLCs also rock and have power to impress you and outshine the basic game.

Large world overall. Lots of things to do. Secrets. High replayability. Humourous. Stylish.

Borderlands 2 is a rpg, Fps. This game is worth the money but not only is it an fps but quite wacky and bizzare making it one of the most unique and different game of all time. Borderlands 2 contains quite a few dlc that last very long. It also have 3 headhunter dlc which are short and only give out alot of skins and heads for your character.

Borderlands 2 has a wide variety of bosses and mini-bosses such as knuckledragger,boom-bewm and captain flynt. Borderlands 2 a great solo game but when friends come on its raid boss time! Raid bosses are tough bosses and usually need a few peopel to defeat. An example is terramorphous, He is a big powerful monster who can wipe you off the map. Some raid bosses are Hyperius, Master Gee, Voracidous and dexidous.

Borderlands 2 has a million different types of weapons, Many are found randomly but some 'Unique' weapons which are usually marked with red text saying something about the weapon. Every boss in borderlands 2 drops a unique which you will need to farm for. Farming is when you fight the boss over and over again for his rarest loot. Some bosses only have a 1 in 200 chance of dropping their unique. Raid bosses drop and legendaries.

Borderlands 2 is a great game and easily a 9.5 out of 10

reviewText: First of all, I strongly recommend getting the Game of the Year edition if you can, for only a few bucks more during a sale, you get so much more DLC. If you don't get the GOTY edition, at least get the Tiny Tina DLC.\n\nThe game is very cartoony and injects a lot of humor (sometimes dark) into the gameplay and dialogs. This game is a bit different from other FPSs in the sense that there are a lot of upgrades and level ups, and once you finish the main game, you can enter True Vault Hunter Mode, a harder version of the game where enemies are leveled up, and then again as Ultimate Vault Hunter mode, where enemies are even more scaled up. My only gripe with this game is that only legendary class weapons (the highest tier) become relevant later in the game, and you will pretty much sell/ignore all other drops, and there is no real money sink for you to spemd all your excess cash. Farming the legendaries can be brutal sometimes, where you can fight the same boss 100 times and still not receive a legendary drop. Still, I would rate this game as one of the top 3 games I've ever played.

reviewText:
(Just humour me for a moment and pretend like you've somehow never heard of this game before) Hey, JacquesLeSauve, what's this Borderlands 2 game I keep hearing about?! Well, mister and/or miss random person gamer, since you ask!...

Borderlands 2 is a first-person, co-op, loot-hunting shooter with RPG elements, and, it might surprise you to know, the sequel to Borderlands 1! (and technically the Pre-squeal, but that's kind of a grey area) Play through a lengthy campaign as one of four characters, each with their own unique abilities and upgradable skill trees to compliment those abilities. Complete quests, fight badasses, earn money, level up and explore the strange and wonderful world of Pandora, all the while searching for that hot new gun that's gonna seriously f*ck sh*t up and ruin everyone else's day. Sweet.

The perfect antidote to an endless array of grey and brown shooters, this vibrant, cel-shaded style game refuses to take any part of itself seriously, save for the gameplay. Brimming with personality, it never misses a chance to hit the player with an off-colour joke or make fun of either itself or gaming in general, with a large portion of that magic being owed to the brilliant writing. The vast majority of characters fit into their roles perfectly and are expertly voiced as well, which is a huge breath of fresh air given how lacklustre the writing and acting can be in so many other games that have yet to learn how to feel natural or not completely chew up the scenery. OK, maybe the main villain is guilty of that heavy-handedness as he's so manifestly evil he goes beyond caricature or archetype and smacks of the creators trying way too hard to rile the player up and make them hate him. But even then he rarely outstays his welcome for too long.

Gunplay is pretty much rock solid as everything feels like it behaves exactly the way it's supposed to, whether it's firing something big and heavy and primitive that makes a big boom, or something more elegant and finely balanced for those scalpel-like precision kills. Even reloading a weapon can feel immensely satisfying, between the reload animation itself or the nice, big clunking sounds of a clip being jammed into place... a sentence I never thought I'd hear myself say. Now I feel weird, like a freaky gun fetishist. Eurgh. But yeah, for a game all about shooting, this nails it for sure... even though I'm the type of player that likes to bring a knife to a gun fight. But either way, whatever you're into, this game has you covered.

Speaking of having you covered, I really have to mention the online community. I'm not much one for online play typically, be it co-operatively or competitively, so not being massively familiar with it, I was a little apprehensive going into this, especially hearing horror stories about a few other communities, so I was expecting the worst. But I was really pleasantly surprised at just how nice and friendly and (mostly) competent the majority of other players seem to be. Sure, you'll occasionally get the odd palindromic loot tool come along and grab all the best gear for themselves, ignore other players in need, then talk cr*p about everyone else when no-one comes to their rescue. But in my experience most players here are incredibly nice and considerate and generous (I especially love the loot fairies"

reviewText:
Borderlands 2 is a blast in co-op, and an improvement over its predecessor in almost every way, but still retains that lonely, barren feeling when played solo.  Missions and environments are more varied and interesting; classes, skill trees and weapons are more fun; PC-specific improvements including adjustable FOV, better gamepad compatibility etc. Vanilla vs vanilla it decimates the original Borderlands.

There isn't as much enemy variety as I would've liked and, while the environments are more varied, they're still mostly limited to inherently barren environments (ice, desert, wastelands).  I would've liked to see more lush environments but perhaps this is being/will be addressed in the DLC.  There are minor bugs like your loot falling through the earth along with real problems such as inventory space being extremely limited, considering it's a loot game.  In spite of this, the game is polished and solid all the way through.

One of the top quality games of the year; got the nasty taste of Diablo 3 out of my mouth. Highly recommended if you plan on co-op.

reviewText:
So, a few years after the FIRST Borderlands came out, I developed a deep hatred for it. I though it looked stupid. I still haven't played the first one to this day (I missed the sale), but I grabbed this mainly because a friend said we could play together (we have not since).

But hey, part of what makes me LOVE this game so much is because SO many people still actively play it. I swear, every time I've started playing, and sometime during the session, one of my friends asks if they can join my game and/or I can join theirs. Some people don't intend on making me feel like a noob—though they do and I'm okay with it/don't say anything—but it's so fun! The game has the most unique online systems I've ever seen IN a video game, and everyone just has a ton of fun~

The game itself is very similar to Bioshock (thanks 2K) in the means of shooting, crazy-♥♥♥ weapons (MUCH more so here) and looting. A LOT of looting. You could spend hours in the game literally making little progress, but looting EVERY container you can find, and there are plenty of secrets to find, too! I'm sure those secrets go with a few achievments, but again, if you don't want to spend hours...they're just achievemnts, dude; I know it's hard to resist, but it really can get tiring looting everything.

The game's got a LOT of humor, and a LOT of unique storyteling/characters that help with that. It's an experience EVERYONE deserves to enjoy. And I feel bad I looked at this franchise the wrong way at first.

reviewText: Borderlands 2 is the sequel to the 2009 game Borderlands, it continues the story of another vault opening in pandora and more vault hunters trying to retrieve its goods. You play as either an assassin, a siren, a gunzerker, or a commando, unless you are willing to pay more to unlock the mechromancer and psycho. Borderlands 2 has guns, a lot of guns. There are literally (almost) infinite types of different guns; the game uses a complex algorithm to produce many different guns, inserting different prefixes and stats each time. This game is well designed with stunning comic book style graphics. I would definitely recommend this to anyone fond of the action-adventure fps sub-genre. 92/100

reviewText:
Ladies and Badassmen.
The first and most important thing about this game is that it's super badass. Also, it's a sequel to a badass game.
What I must do at first is to compare what they did to the game. It was improved in some ways and there were bad decisions as well.

Most notably, the new minimap is awful compared to the old HUD, also, the ingame menu and inventory is awful as well. Well, I'm highly critical, but that's all, everything else remained the same or was improved, maybe changed in a way which is not better or worse either.

Well, one thing I don't like is that Gearbox still have no clue about difficulty levels, like the first Borderlands, some minibosses are invincible, while some huge act bosses are pathetic weaklings. Mad Mike you son of a...
Also, it's still nearly impossible - without golden keys - to get any decent weapon under lvl20 or so, but this is called character progression"

reviewText:
Borderlands 2 is a big game. The sprawling cooperative shooter has arrived, delivering long hours of shooting, looting, and butt jokes. Well, almost intact. Game design changes, like changing the enemy death animations, do a good job of cutting corners while preserving the core action. Technical shortcomings, however, leave little doubt that this is the lesser version of Gearbox's great sequel. Dialogue and sound effects frequently sound flat and occasionally disappear, while the frame rate often slows down in combat and makes the chaotic action feel unwieldy.

Combat in Borderlands 2 is naturally a bit floaty and loose, largely due to way player movement and enemy behavior are paced. As a result, it can accommodate the small degree of control imprecision added by the touchscreens and be none the worse for it. Likewise, the smaller range of motion of the analog sticks may cause some making the PC/console transition to balk a bit, and indeed, aiming can initially feel ungainly if you're used to the game on other platforms. After you adjust the aim sensitivity and spend some time wandering the wastelands, however, the mercenary satisfactions of long-range headshots and up-close bullet barrages are well within reach.

Pros:
Its a good game +
Long story +
wide variety of guns +
Large World +

Cons:
You have to be on the same level to play together (in some cases only) (Multiplayer)
Character skills menu is broken (Skills menu)
In skills menu Main Protagonist is invisible, sometimes loads after some mins (Skills menu)

My ratings,
8.5/10 :)

reviewText:
One of the most entertaining games I've ever played with and the FIRST game which really made me laugh.

It's one thing that the game is beautiful, the story is more than decent, it's not just funny but rather hilarious, the looting is unbelievably rewarding, what is more the DLCs which provide extra stories are well worth the money, but what I liked the most that it's full with smart references to movies and music and lots of other stuff which I probably missed or just didn't understand. I found these references  - from Led Zeppelin until Twin Peaks - in the names of the achievements, missions, but you will also recognise a few stuff when your crazy enemies are running towards you and shouting in your face, or you just pass by somebody in the middle of nowhere and of course, you can find these in the main story too.

Borderlands 2 is a lot of fun, especially with friends.

reviewText: It seems crass to judge a game by quantity, but this is quantity of quality. So if the amount of money you spend on games is a practical concern, it's worth saying that this one is freakishly good value. Even if it's not a concern, it's worth saying that this one is freakishly good.There's really only one conclusion to be made with Borderlands 2. Despite its flaws it really is some of the best co-op gaming you're likely to see in recent years, if you like piles of guns, lots to do and shoot, and a robust leveling system with a natural coop multi-player aspect and aren't put off by the cel shading, it's a no-brainer. 8½/10
voteText: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The game that keeps on giving. Borderlands 2 is a loud, colourful mess of shooting, looting, idiocy and even more idiocy, and is one of the finest multiplayer experiences I know. It's made even more addictive by the extensive RPG elements.

If you have Nvidia PhysX available, you ought to enable it because Gearbox have really made use of it in Borderlands 2. Fight scenes become a cacophonous rainbow of silliness that leave you craving more every time.

They really missed a trick when it comes to weapons though. There are countless weapons in the game but they can't really be customised with scopes, suppressors or elemental effects. If you find a weapon, you can either take it or leave it. Here's hoping Borderlands 3 will address that issue and allow players to piece together the perfect loadout for their play style.

If you are looking for realism in your shooters, try elsewhere, but if all you want is NGHGHHYEAHHH then Borderlands 2 is for you.

reviewText:
Borderlands 2: Probably the best game I've ever gotten from a friend. (Thanks [A.C.E] ACEALEC︻デ═一 for getting me this game) It combines the good parts of shooters, with an impressive, dark story, and also some amazing characters. I usually keep this stuff towards the end, but I'm gonna be honest with you: This is probably one of the finest games of last generation. To the review!

Graphics
The visuals were annoying at first and still are, but I began to grow into the comic styled visuals and then thought it looked great. However, some enemies had poor textures along with lots of the environment. The characters look great, the buildings look awesome, but the environments, many of the enemies (Not all, though. Some look great) have odd textures or look poorly done. When it comes to comic graphics, it's either a hit or a miss. I say Borderlands 2 was successful, but I can't say that it was out of the park good. Overall though, I like it.

Gameplay
The gameplay, which is tied for first as Borderlands 2's (BL2 for short) strong point, takes the good parts of shooters" and along with countless loot

reviewText:
What can i say about this game. I Can't stop playing it. I already had this game on PS3 with around 200 hours on there, and when it came on sale on steam i couldn't resist. An FPS/RPG/Co-op game, you can play with your friends, play single player, or play online, and i can guarantee you won't get bored. Thousands of weapons leaves choices open to how you want to play, and with 6 utterly different classes to choose from, there are a number of awesome, fun ways to play.

I had bought Borderlands 1 a few months after it came out and played it for many hours, completeing the game on 2 characters, and i enjoyed it so much, when i saw that they were releasing Borderlands 2 i honestly thought that it couldn't get any better. Well they made it better all right. If you have have played number 1 or if you havn't then i still highly recommend this game.

The storyline is brilliant, funny, and a lot of fun. Some of the characters are hilarious and brilliantly thought out, and the story will keep you laughing all the way. The graphics and excellent, with a mix of cartoony and realism all mixed in, much like Borderlands 1. The gameplay is also fantastic, with so many different ways to kill enemys and different playstyles. One of the best games i have ever played.

10/10 from me, highly recommend!

reviewText:
Borderlands 2 like its predecessor is a role playing shooter. You begin your adventure as the victim of train sabotage by Handsome Jack. And awaken from catastrophe relatively unscathed at the feet of Claptrap. Claptrap eventually leads you to resistance against Handsome Jack, led by the original four characters from Borderlands. The story has seen improvement over the original. The quality writing as a whole has drastically increased from first insulation, but it’s made not for story structure but in the dialog as well. From the dialog alone, I predict that Handsome Jack will start appearing top 10 favorite villain list over the internet sometimes soon. He has a great personality, his funny human and ultimately very very evil.


The journey will rack you-in over 30 hours to complete the main quest line. That’s if you don’t do any side missions, go off exploring, team up with friends and their games. Borderlands 2 is a time enthralling but I mean the most enduring way possible. No matter if you catch the game on sale or if you pay full price, you will get your money’s worth. It’s jam packed with quality content from start to finish. If I use the term “finish” likely because once you complete the main quest, you can play thru the entirely game again against harder and more diverse enemies that drop more elaborate guns and gear pushing you seemingly temporary cap of level fifty.


In that regard, Borderlands 2 is like an MMO but one you only experience with friends and strangers if you want to. Teaming up with your friends and strangers is as easy as flickering on light switch. Cooperative gameplay not only exponentially increases the fun factor with your friends, but it also causes the game to spawn tougher enemies and better loot. There are plenty of bad-♥♥♥ awards, permanent perks for performing various in-game task that can only be achieve with help from your friends.


Graphically, Borderlands 2 has seen a significant facelift over the original but still uses the same art style. I ran on several different graphics but somehow hard time pushing few of the games more fantastic effects when there was tons of actions on the screen. But all in all, I am very pleased that way the game performed. I experienced very few crashes and my connectivity issues were hammered out by the third day of gameplay. The varied locations grade from deserts, to rocky mountain ranges, to green steps, to snowy wastelands, to urban environments and industrial complexes located in the world’s harshest terrain. You’ll be fighting classic enemies like skag, rakk and pyscho but there is also nice variety of new beast, malcontents and machines.


Getting from point A to Z in Borderlands 2, can be done either by foot, car or fast travel stations. Considering the massive size of the entire world, you’ll be happy for any type of transportation after a particularly grew some firefight session. It is important to note that driving cars on PC, takes some getting used to. But most of all, I am slightly disappointed to see that enemies clearly have air superiority over you with transforming robots and buzzard drop ships. This isn’t necessarily negative mark against Borderlands 2 or a side note. I really really want to fly those buzzards around in the available areas within Pandora.


Despite everything I love about Borderlands 2, it definitely has an ugly side to it. Unfortunately, it comes from the multiplayer. Joining cooperative games which I haul hardly recommend on doing. It can have some massively negative repercussions to your single player experience. You can miss entire chunks of the storyline and game important unlocks by hopping on with players who are only few levels ahead of you depending where you are in the game. Even though Borderlands 2 offers a system to counter this possibility, it’s not 100% effective. And sadly, there is no Replay Mission option available which could potentially resolve this issue entirely.


I love Borderlands 2 and truly love it. Certainly, there are few dense in the hall but all in all its exemplary experience from start to finish whether you play along or with friends. I can easily say one of the best cooperative games I’ve played this generation and easily one of my favorite first person shooter as well.

reviewText: I love Borderlands 2\n
voteText: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Shooting games aren't usually my cup of tea but then there's Borderlands. The first game was a game that I sunk a large number of hours into (steam lies) because of how much fun it offered, Borderlands 2 takes everything that the first game has to the next level and adds even more.

The characters in the game have amusing dialogue that is rather funny and interesting, each has a different style and a unique personality, whether it's Cl4P-TP, Scooter, Handsome Jack or any of the many other character you'll encounter throughout the many adventures on Pandora.

While missions are usually to kill other creatures there's still a large diversity and I never felt that I was doing the same thing except for maybe some of the missions in the Sir Hammerlock's Big Game Hunt DLC.

The game offers a number of DLCs and while that could be bad practice I have to give them credit for at least 2 of the main DLCs: Captain Scarlett and Her Pirate's Booty, and Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep for being excellent (I can even go as far as saying that Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep is beyond excellent and because of it Borderlands 2 is now my favorite game). Mr. Torgue's Campaign of Carnage DLC is good fun, and Sir Hammerlock’s Big Game Hunt has its strong points but has some bad ones as well.

The game provides an interesting story line as opposed to its predecessor in addtion to connecting it to what little of story the first one did. There are moments of pure nostalgia for Borderlands fans, as well as plenty of easter eggs and references to all kind of different games, movies, and TV shows that kept me smiling throughout the game.

The game has very high replayability value, aside from 6 unique classes each class can be played in many different styles thanks to the massive number of different weapons and skills combinations, and the addition of the badass rank and badass tokens with the large collection of challenges, it also helps that the scenery and lighting ingame are impressive and beautiful to look at. Exploring everything and taking my time to finish most challenges I already have over 100 hours on a single character and I'm not yet done with all the DLCs on the Normal Mode, I still have many more hours before I even start True Vault Hunter Mode and Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode on that character alone.

reviewText:
Playing since 2013, now still playing by time to time. Because it really have fun to replay!

+Random weapon attribute
+Random Legendary weapon (Outstanding shooting mode)
+Ammo & crash is easy to loot
+Relic / Shield / Grenade / Class mode!
+Upgradable capacity of inventory & ammo storage
+Allow to sort inventory (by manufacturers, type, misc, all)
+A lot side quests
+Each mission show difficulties to compare current level
+Allow to sort mission (by difficulties, area, all)
+Player allow to ignore quest, the quest will be at bottom on the list
+Interesting story character
+Long adventure (Playing coop will very fast to complete & level up)
+Replayable character
+4 variety character ability (Spell & Melee too)

-Lack of diversity cover area, combat encounter
-Playing solo is very hard to continue, advice to play side mission to levelup or Coop
-During a boss fight, player cant go other place
-Not able to switch character during gameplay

reviewText:
Borderlands 2 attempts to step up from the first game, but in the end they don't deviate much from the original setup. There's guns, loot, ridiculous characters, and EXPLOSIONS.

One thing I enjoyed, is that this game is just a heck of a lot more FUN. The voiceovers are great, some of the characters will bust your gut (Torque and Tiny Tina), and the ongoing lines from Jack always tow the line between seriously-going-to-kill-you and I-need-to-crack-a-joke territory.

The controls and gameplay are solid once again, and I had a relatively bug free experience on the PC. If you are an achievement hound, get ready for a few achievements that will drive you batty. The Challenge Accepted achievement takes more time to complete than the main campaign does, but man does it feel good to land it.

My biggest complaint with the Borderlands series continues to be with how stinkin' easy the game is. Yes, they added Ultimate Vault Hunter mode and made the baddies better (also the overleveling DLC), but I'm concerned with the original campaign. I want my first playthrough to be challenging. It took me all of a minute to defeat the final boss on my first playthrough, do you know how unsatisfying that is? Instead of building the game around a pre-set structure of levels for opponents, why not structure the first playthrough where all enemies level up with you? Nothing is worse than coasting through the final mission while shooting a gun that's ten levels above your worst enemy.

Overall, it's a game that's very fun to play and has reasonable replay value, but you won't find many surprises here if you played the first.

reviewText:
Summary (TL;DR)
This game is the peak of the series, bringing in new and refreshing characters while letting you work alongside the original four from Borderlands 1. With this installment of the game, Co-op is even more fun now with new vehicles, weapons, and enemies to hunt down, along with characters old and new being introduced and reintroduced to the story.

The game also often questions your morality... but you will have to play to learn more about that.

Pros    Fun gameplay
Original Graphics
Great storyline
Co-op doesn't feel like everything is too easy
Claptrap is as annoying as ever
Great character skill trees
High replay value

Cons    Many filler" missions
Skill trees can't be fully completed

reviewText:
Borderlands 2 is a very mixed bag. At times, it can be incredibly fun, as you unload shotgun pellets into Psycho Midget faces and throw buzz axes at a Goliath's head. At other times, it can be an incredibly tedious game as you backtrack from place to place and are forced to perform some infurating timed quests. The same can be said for its juvenile sense of humor. At times, it can be a very funny game, but at plentyof other times, you'll groan at how dumb a joke was or how awful a reference was.

Let's get the biggest issue out of the way first. This game is terribly boring in the first couple of hours. You barely have any variety in combat, you have very few and very weak weapons, and you don't really have any interesting quests. It's a slog through the campaign until you get enough skill points in your character to make the game fun. For example, in my playthrough as Krieg the Psycho, it was a boring experience until I got enough points in cooldown reductino to let me spam my active ability freely.

And on that note, we look at another big flaw of Borderlands 2: the skill tree. Every character gets only one active skill, such as being able to dual wield guns, turn invisible, or summon a giant mech of death. While this improves the variety of combat greatly at first, you don't get any of the more interesting or game changing abilities until your character is at a very high level (31 or more). Until then, you're stuck with (mostly) boring percentage stat boosts that barely affect your playstyle. To the game's credit, there are a hanful of interesting skills that do change how you play significantly, but there aren't enough of them. If there was more than one active skill, then the skill tree would be a little more tolerable, but as it stands, it's a grind to get the skills that you actually want.

Next on the chopping block is the music and gun sounds. The guns, more often than not, sounds incredibly weak. You often feel like you're firing a peashooter, not a quad barreled shotgun. It's all incredibly underwhelming, to be honest. The music is fine, but it does a very poor job of pumping your adrenaline. That is, the music never helps you feel like the badass that the game wants you to be.

My next major complaint is the loot system, in that it's not very good. There are some interesting weapons and drops, but more often than not, you'll get crappy guns that you'll just throw away because they're too weak or underleveled. This wouldn't be so bad if guns scaled to your current level, but since they don't, you'll be getting a lot of trash in proportion to useful equipment.

Also, the performance of this game is not very consistent. At times, I can get 120 FPS no problem, but when I turn 180 degrees, it become a quarter of what it was a second ago. After trying numerous engien tweaks and reducing graphical fidelity, not much improves the performance of this game (I run a 780 Ti, so it's a very capable rig). It's not a dealbreaking, but it is very annoying.

Finally, the story is very threadbare, despite Gearbox's efforts to improve it this time around. The entire story can be summed up to: Handsome Jack is a ♥♥♥♥, go kill Jack. I mean, the story does its job in getting you from place to place and ferrying you to a wide variety of locales, but it really isn't anything memorable.

So, now onto the good.

The combat can be really fun late game when your character is properly specced out. Having a maxed out Mania tree in Krieg is a blast as you one shot enemies with your melee weapon or snipe them from afar with your thrown buzz axes. You'll eventually get some interesting guns that have some very powerful effects that mesh with your playstyle or change it up.

Co-op is pretty seamlessand allows you to drop into and out of a friend's game quickly. Enemies will become tougher, and loot will become better, so it's definitely the way to play if you have a couple of good buddies.

The voice acting, in general, is very well done. Solid deliveries by the cast all around, and there are some very well delivered lines (pretty much anything by Handsome Jack is well voiced, for example). There really aren't any characters that get get on your nerves, unless you find Ashley Burch's voice grating.

Finally, the game can be incredibly funny in its own stupid way. If you embrace the cheese of the game and accept stupid jokes like bonerfarts"

reviewText: What a fantastic game!  While the experience is much better if you can round up a couple of friends, this game is still very much enjoyable as a single player experience.  I have easily logged over 100+ hours on this game on console, both as single player and as multiplayer.  Combining the fast paced action of a first person shooter with the addictive nature of leveling and loot finding from an rpg, Borderlands 2 is a new beast altogether.  Add in a competent story and this game will suck you in for dozens of hours.  Even if you're not a big shooter fan I would say give this a try, as it relies less on twitch gaming and more on planning and strategy.  With multiple classes that play differently, this is a game that you could easily play through more than once.  Solid controls and soundtrack only add to the experience.  Overall, this is one of the best gaming experiences you can have this generation.  I give this game a 9/10.

reviewText: This is more of an addictive hobby than a game.  Take the old Doom games, update the graphics with a cartoony look and then throw in a great story and some RPG elements and you have Borderlands 2.  The loot in the game is maybe the most addictive feature, the items you acquire can be great but they loose their luster (and power) as you level up so you are constantly searching for better gear and items... this leads to playing the game in search of legendary items (loot midgets anyone?) at higher and higher levels.  Each character can play through the game three times (more really, since you can reset your progress in Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode, if you get that far) and with all the DLC available for this game, that means hundreds of hours of gameplay.  If you're an addict of the game like me, get all the DLC for it including the headhunter stuff because it all contributes to the greatness of Borderlands 2.  I've mainly played as Gaige but I've also tried out the Gunzerker too.  I've sunk over 200+ hours into the game as of the writing of this review and I'm still looking forward to playing as the Siren and the Psycho.  Be warned... if you get into the this game, I mean really get into it, you'll have a long stay on Pandora and the real world will become a serious nuisance because it will limit your ability to play Borderlands 2.

reviewText: You are not in Kansas anymore. You are on Pandora, ladies and gentlemen. Respect that fact every second of every day. If there is a Hell, you might wanna go there for some R & R after a tour on Pandora. Out there beyond that fence every living thing that crawls, flies, or squats in the mud wants to kill you and eat your eyes for jujubes. We have an indigenous population of humanoids called the Psycho's. They're fond of saws that are dipped in their enemies blood. Those blades will stop your heart in one minute - and have brains equal to a bowl of mush. They are very easy to kill. As a random vault hunter, it is my job to keep you revived. I will not succeed. Not with all of you. If you wish to survive, you need to cultivate a strong lack of moral sense.

reviewText: This game, despite not having better graphical quality than other RPG games, it is one of the best games I've played. The fact that the game's setting which takes place in the years 5252 does not convince me much about the technological advancement as compared to the present (other than the fact that you can download your own vehicle from any catch-a-ride machine), but Gearbox's most famed game is not just an awesome game, it's beyond that. There are 3 playthrough modes, 6 characters to play on, and thousands of different variants of weapons to choose from. And then there are unique weapons, which signifies that these weapons will act in a unique way upon being fired, rather than just having its bullets fired in a straight line. Normal Mode was relaxing and enjoyable, TVHM was more intense, and UVHM (including the Overpower levels) is tougher and is recommended for hardcore gamers. I could go on, but this is truly an awesome, must-play game. Hats off to the game developers.

reviewText:
You have to reeeeeeeeeeeeeally love Borderlands to get the most out of this one. Otherwise you just get sick of it relatively quickly like I did. Even still, you may think you love Borderlands a lot after playing the first one, and think you'll really love this one too, and then realize that maybe you don't like it as much as you thought.

Objectively speaking, everything about BL2 is better than the first. It's incredibly polished, loaded with content, easier to play with friends (or strangers), highly replayable (that is, if you reeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeally love Borderlands). So much improvement, but just not as addicting. Exploring is pointless because there's nothing to find, and the only good weapons come from grinding bosses. I just couldn't get hooked like I did on the first one.

Mostly fun while it lasted, but I'm so bored of it all, and it's feeling like a chore just forcing myself to finish the last (and apparently best) DLC. The humor is enjoyable too, I suppose, but it quickly becomes predictable.

All in all, I'm in a strange place with this recommendation. If I could go back in time and tell myself not to get it and that I wouldn't enjoy it as much, past-me wouldn't believe future-me and would still buy this game and it's DLC anyway. I can't say I regret the 107 hours spent playing this game, but I can't say it was time well spent either.

Curiosity satisfied, Borderlands hunger satiated, that's it for me. Thanks Gearbox and 2K, but I won't be getting BL3.

reviewText:
4 Stars - A colourful shooter with strong co-op functionality.

This was my first entrant to the Borderlands games and I was impressed. Although not the most precise shooter this game was a lot of fun. The core game plays through a loose storyline that can be solo or co-op. Weapons are regularly looted and can be quite diversive, enabling the player to find a combo that suits.

The borderlands is humoursly filled with pyscho's (good and bad) as well as a plethora of dangerous natural inhabitants and the over-arching presence of Jack who plays the key villian role (well).

Overall I found the co-op play through of this to be very satisfying and I recommend giving it a go.

Pros -
Co-Op
Art design / Plot aspects / World atmosphere
Weapon Design

Cons -
The loot generator will throw out some guns that are just crap and these should be avoided
Gun specs can mislead the player as guns appear more about fit than numbers. Over analysing weapon choices may distract from game play

reviewText:
Sup, sucka?

Oh boy, Borderlands 2. This game is amazing and hilarious and brilliant and...pew-pew-pew!

Meh f*ck it, reviews are boring and usually have too many syllables.You don't wanna read an another review, Vault Hunter! You wanna read about LOOT! AND PECS! AND EXPLOSIONS! Besides, did you know that ninety-seven percent of all living things on Pandora aren't exploding right now? That's b*llshit!  You can’t let this happen, can you? So here is what you need to do: Buy the game, bring friends, collect shiny loot, strip the flesh, salt the wound, enjoy the mayhem, blow sh*t up, and obliterate all kind of nasty ultimate badass enemies whom you can find across the planet.

Are you still reading this crap? Alright then. Let me share with you an actual quote from Handsome Jack who is, without question, the real hero of this story:

Argh this is so frustrating! You see, this is what I don’t get about you bad guys.You know the hero’s gonna win, but you just don’t die quickly! Example: This one guy in New Haven, right? City’s burning, people are dying left and right yada yada yada...This jackhole rushes me with a spoon. A frickin’ spoon! And I’m dying laughing, right? So I scoop out his stupid little eyeballs with it and his kids are all “whaaaahh”, and he can’t see where he’s going, he’s bumping into stuff and... [*laughing*] Ah, I don’t know, maybe you had to be there. The moral is: YOU’RE A TOTAL B*TCH!

Yeah. This sums it up. Borderlands 2 for ya. And remember: Real badasses eat chocolate chip cookies.

reviewText:
Genre: Action, RPG.
Developer: Gearbox Software.
Publisher: 2K Games.
Release Date: 21 Sep, 2012


STORY It has exciting, dramatic parts, to emotional and sad parts. Borderlands 2 always keeps you on your toes. The story is set on a planet called Pandora, which has an uninvited guest, a company called Hyperion. The leader, Handsome Jack, wants to mine a mysterious alien element called eridium, to open a ruin on Pandora called, The Vault. You, and/or your friends are tasked with saving the planet, and defeating Handsome Jack. As well as a main story, there are also side quests, which contain their own stories within them. There are hundreds of side quests in the game for you to explore, and if need be, build XP on to level up.

MULTIPLAYER Borderlands 2 multiplayer gameplay is much the same as the single player, but the difficulty ramps up heavily when you get more friends involved in co-op. The difficulty level adapts to the level of your characters so if you’ve got four fairly well levelled friends in a game, be prepared for some serious battles.

Gameplay
It's a first-person shooter, gameplay is going to be the main part in it. This game is filled with action almost all the time. There are dozens of types of enemies which can harm you in different ways. The game may make you rely on different types of weapons. For example, an armoured enemy will take more damage from a corrosive weapon, an enemy with a shield will take more damage from an electric weapon, or an enemy with no defense would take even more damage from an incendiary weapon. This can be awkward if you don't have those weapons. As I mentioned before, this game is amazing if you have friends playing it with you. The more people in a game with you, the harder the enemies, but also the better the loot. Go through an epic journey exploring the wilds, completing side quests and complain about who gets what weapon.

Design & Graphics
Borderlands 2, as you can see by the screenshots, is a very cartoonish game, but not in the way you might imagine it. Although cartoonish, It's actually beautiful. Some environments leave you stunned. Graphics can be adjusted in the settings to make the game look even more pretty. If you don't have a perfect PC, this game can lag quite a lot, and the FPS can go down really low. Again, for the design, It's sublime. Almost everything is detailed. Open wildernesses are detailed quite well. The only negative thing I'll mention is mushy backdrops in some places.

AudioThe soundtrack of this game were composed by Jesper Kyd, a well-known composer for video games and movies. There are 23 songs in all featured on the official Borderlands 2 Soundtrack with well over an hour of great tunes to tantalize your ear buds. Many of the songs are featured heavily or in key moments of Borderlands 2, but it is a little saddening to know that not all of the songs featured in the game made the cut for the soundtrack. The official Borderlands 2 Soundtrack is a great listen and even features an adequate amount of wub wub for those of you that are into that sort of thing.


---- PROS ----

Great storyline.
Co-op doesn't feel like everything is too easy.
Fun gameplay.
Easter eggs.
Hilarious characters.
Great soundtrack.
Epic DLCs.
Unlimited guns.


---- CONS ----
Inventory space is a bit too small.
Shared loot drops.
Location in a map is not saved when exiting the game.


Borderlands 2 is a perfect game, which is worth hundreds of hours of playtime. Whether it be alone or with friends.

Score Rating: 8.7/10

reviewText:
This game is near flawless.  With exciting AND addictive game-play that stays fresh even past the 2nd play-through I am never board with this game.  Especially considering how easy it really is to play with friends.  I do wish it was more possible for people of different level ranges to play together but we cant have it all.
In stark contrast to the first Borderlands, the story is actually compelling and the superb voice acting makes it hard not to be drawn in.  The humor plays a big part as well and never feels out of place in the abstract Borderlands universe.
The graphics look great on both high AND mid range systems, offering highly stylized graphics that still have a touch of realism.
In closing I must commend Gearbox Software for their love-letter to the PC community.  Literally every gripe I had with the shoddy console-port that was BL1 is gone.  This game truly deserved Game of the Year.

reviewText: Borderlands 2 is a hectic and thoroughly enjoyable First person RPG shooter.  While replaying the main storyline campaign can get repetitive after a few times, the amount and variety of DLC content keeps the game feeling fresh.  The game comes stock with 4 distinct classes and has two additional ones available through paid DLC.  Each class plays differently and with the talent tree choices even playing the same class over can feel slightly different.  The length of the main story campaign feels decently long but can be rushed through relatively quickly.  That's why I highly suggest playing through all of the available side quests and EXPLORE.  That is one of the bigger selling points of this game for me.  While the story itself can feel linear and pushing you from zone to zone.  The amount of extra quests and areas to discover is great.  I highly recommend this game to fans of the borderlands franchise and newcomers alike.

reviewText: Loot and Shoot has never been better. Honestly I have no idea why I didn't get into the Borderlands franchise sooner. This game took everything that was amazing with the first Borderlands and made it 100x MORE BADASS! The characters are well developed and the game just in general is one of the best experiences I've had with a shooter. The guns really are on a whole different level this time around especially with the new element introduced known as slag. I won't go too much into slag but let me just say its a great addition to anyone's arsenal. There's a trading system that is very useful to players and if you want to fight for your guns just start a trade and enter a duel for a winner takes all situation. The enemies are very diverse and some can even evolve mid combat such as the goliath and varkids, which offers plenty of challenge if you let them power up. The game also rewards returning players of the first borderlands as you can interact with the original vault hunters as well as a return of some familiar guns (hellfire, volcano, bone shredder, etc.). Stop reading this and go buy it! It's a game you will NOT regret playing

reviewText: Borderlands is about having a ridiculous variety of guns, and killing many, many things with them.  Borderlands 2 is also about that, but also about killing all of those things in multiplayer.  With enemies forever scaling to be just above your level, Borderlands 2 is more difficult to play solo than the first game was.  It's still a lot of fun, but as someone who would usually not play multiplayer, Borderlands 2 is not as fun as the original.  It is certainly worth playing though, and at this stage you can get the GOTY edition pretty cheaply, so go kill things to death.

reviewText: Borderlands 2  Borderlands 2 is the sequel of the same name but quite telling the different stories. In the game we can play as one of four main characters: Salvador (gunzerker), Maya (siren), Zero (assasin) and Axton (commando). Each of these characters has a different special skills, abilities and use different types of weapons. In the game, we will have to visit the various places of the mysterious planet Pandora. During the game we will fight a fight between different monsters, bandits or Hyperian forces but our biggest enemy is Handsome Jack. We also assign a fight with a bit more more powerful enemies and bosses are more precisely. In the game, we have a lot of weapons from pistols to rocket launchers. Our heroes can change the skin. Fields after whose will also move us are very large. The game has a very pretty graphic and very good sound. Creators also offer cooperative mode for a four people and a very nice DLC packages which adds many hours of fun. I highly recommend this game, gameplay is a very funny. My final rating is 9/10.

reviewText: Just pick a few friends and enjoy hours of content that in its majority is basically looting and shooting, but still quite fun and entertaining. I only manage to do one playthrough (3 if you count that I beat it with the same character in the three different difficulties to reach max lvl) and have experience almost the enterity (not all) of the game and its dlcs, took me +150hr. Many people like to make fun of the story because you can play this game without caring much for it but I found it quite entertaining and charismatic. One of the strongest features of this game its the strange sense of humour, sometimes ridiculous and extreme and other times completely dark but that I particularly enjoyed. It's characters are yet another important point. I'll remember Handsome Jack as one of the most emblematic villains as it is a lunatic you get to love and hate at the same time.

reviewText:
This game is amazing, its near perfect, definitely one of the best games I ever played.

PROS:
1- Amazing story
2- GUNS, GUNS, ANYBODY SAID GUNS? GUUUUNS!
3- Interesting environments
4- Intriguing skill trees
5- Enticing loot and experience rewards
6- The game is fun, some characters might be annoying but some of them are funny

CONS:
1- If you wanna experience Borderlands 2 at it fullest, you must get the DLC's, which can be expensive for some
2- Legendary Drops are so rare that I had to solo Terramorphous like 15 times to get what I want.


My rating: 9.5/10
voteText: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText: While BioShock Infinite might be the best game I have ever played, Borderlands 2 is the absulutely best in terms of overall player experience. I have never ever had so much fun as when playing this game. Beautiful graphics, entertaining storyline, probably the best voice acting in all of video game industry, some of the greatest character designs ever made (Claptrap, Tiny Tina and especially Handsome Jack), immense amounts of loots (there are literally millions of guns you can choose from) and excellent replayability. The game has about 200 hours of gameplay if you wish to level a character entirely, which is a lot, but I guarantee you, they will be some of the best moments of your gaming life.\n\nA lot can be said about maturity of the content of the game as well. A lot of harsh language, sexual innuendos and things that would be disgusting in other games (cannibalism, torture and so on) is present, but the game is incredibly mature and deals with all of these themes in a very respectable way, which is further supplemented by the perfect graphics. Not only that, but the game also packs striking thoughts and supports LGBT rights, goes against domestic violence (I will never forget Mr. Torgue saying his best quote ever: YOU BETTER TREAT MOXXI NICE! NOTHING IS MORE BADASS THAN TREATING A WOMAN WITH RESPECT!")
date: regards personal insecurity and many many other important topics in our current society. It does all of this with grace. There is even an NPC created specifically for a now-deceased Borderlands fan - and that is just one of many examples of how great the developers are. Honestly
recommended: Gearbox Software staff are some of the best people I have ever had the pleasure to meet.\n\nThe humour in the game is also something that cannot be possibly overglorified. Not only you will find references to just about every game and pop culture theme ever to be made here
hoursPlayed: but the dialogues are incredibly funny even when discussing important things. The way the game makes fun of itself is something that absolutely captured me. ("Torgue weapons ALWAYS fire EXPLOSIVE ROUNDS. They are also LOUD and require EXCESSIVE use of CAPITAL LETTERS") The fourth wall is broken all the time
voteText: but it is done in a so incredibly funny way that it feels so
helpfulPercent: so right. ("Hey guys
votesHelpful: remember the old Crawmerax the Invincible?" "Sure
votesTotal: we exploited his glitches for HOURS! Oh
votesFunny: Pearlescents!")\n\nThe DLCs are all worth is as well
commentsCount: as they add a lot to the story and offer a lot additional content. Tiny Tina's Assault on the Dragon Keep is probably the greatest DLC ever created for any game ever. The amount of references
column16: fun and interesting enemies present here are incredible. If I had to choose a single game out of all of them and spend the rest of my life playing it
column17: it would be Borderlands 2.\n\nWould I recommend this game? No. No
column18: I do not recommend you to buy this game. I recommend you to head to the Store and buy the Borderlands GOTY Edition
column19: Borderlands 2 GOTY Edition
column20: Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel and it's Season Pass and The Tales of Borderlands as well. Buy the entire franchise. Just. Do. It. Also
column21: write a love letter to Gearbox Software and thank them for creating the best game franchise currently to exist."

reviewText:
To anyone considering buying this game, ask yourself two simple questions.
Do I have friends that would play this with me?
Do I like shooters and/or RPGs?
If you answered yes to either of these questions, then you will enjoy this game. Playing with friends in this game is a great time, even if you dont want to get involved with the story, you will find that shooting your way around the world with up to three other friends is massivley enjoyable. However, boasting an incredibly solid campaign as this, delivering quirky characters and interesting dialogue, this games gives you pleanty of reason to actually get involved in the story. All in all, the campaign scores a 8.7/10 from me, as the multiple runthroughs that I went through did not have me pull my eyes out of my sockets from tedium. *cough* Borderlands 1 arid badlands*cough*
The area that really makes this game shine is the DLCs. The dlcs from this game are, with the community in almost unanimous agreement, better than the actual campaign, which as I said before, is really great.
Finish the game for the first time, then I wholeheartedly recommend you smack those dlcs. With actual raid bosses *cough* Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel and your single Raid" boss which was just a rehash of the last boss(Which dont get me wrong

reviewText:
By the time i'm making this review i have spent 151 hours into this game.
Don't quite know if i regret it but i do know that i did enjoy my time....alot.

Bought this game a year ago, sometime in june last year with little to no expectations all i knew is that i wanted to play a good co op game with my friends.
We played for a couple of hours and i liked it. I kept playing more and more over time realizing that i was in love with this game.

+ Fantastic story in my opinion.
+ Great villain (essential for a good story IMO)
+ Gun Porn
+ When you finish the main storyline you still have plenty of things to do (loads of content)
+ Good replayability
+ Beautiful art style
+Likeable characters.
+ Fun co op with friends
+ Great customization ( Also DLC's for that)
+ Many DLC's story and cosmetic DLC's
+Many classes to choose from
+ Nice easter eggs
+ Game has personality

- Friendship ruining loot system
- Some story parts are told through voice coms while you are fighting mobs, might end up not hearing what was going on due to explosions.
- Time to time connection problems

All though these are just minor setbacks the game is still fantastic. Not perfect but great fun and amazing.
Worth picking up in my opinon.
9/10

reviewText: Grab your friends, give them shootalots and get into da choppa... or atleast bandit roadrunner.\n\nHaving played Borderlands 1 over and over, then jumping onto Borderlands 2 expecting the same mayhem of flying bullets and screaming psychos, I definetely found what I looked for and expected from second installment. Game reintroduces our old Vault Hunters from previous game as NPCs with the feel of nostalgia, we get to play 4 new base heroes with simmiliar mechanics to old ones and introduces two more heroes with brand new mechanics which were made with support and feedback of fanbase since we all were trigger happy in Borderlands 1. We are carried through planet Pandora once again to show us what changed in meantime, then we get to know more and more of Handsome Jack, one of best developed villains of all times (next to Vaas from Far Cry 3). During game we get to shoot out all our happiness, frustration, we laugh a lot and sometimes feel sad, all because of very good made story, which rarely happens in shooter games nowadays.

reviewText:
Borderlands 2 is cross between an RPG regarding the story and a FPS for the action and levelling system.

With randomly generated guns, shields, class & grenade mods, the variation of equipments is staggering, much like the enemies.
From Psycho Midgets holding shotguns bigger than them (that have the most hilarious lines ever written), robots with everything from pistols to nukes, local wildlife that can lob cars at you or tunnel underground and appear with a fiery explosion and a swarm of tentacle like arms to various boss's & a hole host of creatures, humans & AI mechs, under, on or above the surface of Pandora. Which by the way is a beautifully place.
The environment ranges from glaciers, valleys, deserts, roaming hills, caverns, towns & with the expansions even more including a vast landscape produced by a 13year old explosives genius mind, Tiny Tina. A character I hope you will come to love as most of us have.

The main story is brilliant and take you all over Pandora. You can play solo or with up to 3 others, from 1 of 4-6 (DLC dependant) Vault hunters. All with unique abilities, and skill trees that can be changed throughout the game to suite your play style & equipment.

The vast number of optional side missions can provide some very nice loot, insights into the life & history of Pandora or just a good laugh.

The main DLC's (Psycho, Mechromancer, Ultimate Vault Hunter Upgrades 1 & 2, Mr. Torgue's, Sir Hammerlock's, Captain Scarlett & best of all Tiny Tina's) are all worth the coin, the head hunter packs are ok, and the skins are all superficial. But to be fair now the GOTY Edition is out id just get that, then you have the lot, it's so worth it. I'm on 1000+ hours and still coming back to it.

Edit: Spelling

10/10

reviewText:
I will start by saying; I have been playing Borderlands2 for maybe about a week now. I currently have a level 18 Commando. Never did I touch the original Borderlands, and I always wanted to get into it. The commercials on TV always patronized me, and then one day, bam! Someone gifted it to me on Steam. I couldn't believe my eyes.

It is now maybe 3 years later, that I have gotten myself into Borderlands 2 (which, guess what - was gifted to me!) with two other friends. I am absolutely in love.

If you have ever played an MMORPG - the concept is sort of the same. You have to complete quests, and you unlock experience, currencies (Cash, Eridium [usable on black market]), weapons, class mods and whatnot. Of course, there is also DLC you can purchase to further customize your character -- but you do not even have to. You can also unlock OTHER character customizations just by playing.

Loads of fun. Quests can sometimes be confusing on figuring out exactly just where to go, and controlling your first vehicle before you get the Bandit by mouse is EXTREMELY awkward for me.. the wheels don't move by A and S, it moves by the mouse. I know there's a term for that.. but I don't know what it is, and it is 2am in the morning.

Please - get this game. I promise you you will thank me later. And if it's gifted to you - thank that person. I have my own thanks to give. :)

reviewText:
I have played this game for over 1200 hours. As such, I have explored all 6 classes, almost all of the skill sets, tried most of the weapons, etc. How they can make a game fun for as long as I have enjoyed this is beyond me. I played and really liked the first Borderlands, but this one is better yet and I have the pre-sequel already pre-ordered.
While it is not a true sandbox as we have come to know, it gives enough general freedom to explore. It awards those who like to be thorough with up to 69 achievements and a lot of challenges which gives you B@d@$$ points you can spend within the game to make all your characters stronger.
My negatives are relatively minor. The game limits players from leveling above 72, but then introduces over-powered enemies through Raid On Digistruct Peak that then goes up to overpowered 8 (OP8). I understand the logic to this as they don't want everyone to have every skillset. However, there is no way that I know of to look at a level 72 player to know if they are playing as 72 or OP8. There is a big difference in the strength of the items and if an OP8 person joins your standard level 72 game they one-shot-kill everything.
Overall, great game. I love the cooperative aspect. Without it, I wouldn't probably have ever played online. I hope as hardware gets stronger, they can make the graphics better and/or add more players to the mix. I don't think it probably is possible, but being able to game with someone on a console, PC, and MAC would be awesome. Thanks for all the enjoyment Gearbox!

Borderlands 2 Vanilla(no dlc)Overview

Weapons
Just like In Borderlands 1 you have rifles,shotguns,smgs,pistols, & grenades  to play with.They have different status effects with the introduction of a new one called Slag".As far as the vanilla(no dlc) game goes the variety seems not as random as Borderlands 1 though sadly.Not that this detracts from the game even slightly but it might annoy some.

Gameplay & Gamelength
Quests are the usual standard fetch

reviewText: This game is near flawless. With exciting AND addictive game-play that stays fresh even past the 2nd play-through I am never bored with this Game. Especially considering how easy it really is to play with Friends. I do wish it was more possible for people of different Level ranges to play together but we cant have it all.\nIn stark contrast to the first Borderlands, the story is actually compelling and the superb voice acting makes it hard not to be drawn in. The Humor plays a big part as well and never feels out of place in the abstract Borderlands Universe.\nThe Graphics look great on both high and mid range Systems, offering highly stylized Graphics that still have a touch of Realism. In closing I must commend Gearbox Software for their love-letter to the PC community. This Game truly deserved Game of the Year. “You're gonna be my new meat bicycle!” 100/100

reviewText: The hook of Borderlands 2,  is the loot. Guns, ammo, character skins, grenade mods, class mods -- there’s always something just a bit better, something you so desperately didn’t even know you needed until you found it in Borderlands 2. Just like other action RPGs, the hunt for loot becomes intoxicating because of the tiny rush you get each time a rare colored item spills out of a chest or recetly slain enemy. Guns are a bulk of the loot, and that’s great because you’re going to spend most of your time in Borderlands 2 staring down a gun sight.You simply have to decide the best -- or most entertaining -- way to kill everyone. Borderlands 2 is a much needed improvements to areas like narrative and class skill design to Borderlands. Overall this is an amazing shooter no one even remotely curious should overlook.

reviewText:
1. If you have any interest in this game, buy it
2. If you don't like it (even though thats practically impossible), Go back to Step 1

Pros
-Sh♥tloads of guns
-Funny dialogue
-Interesting and unique characters
-ALOT OF GUNS
-Not a Military FPS (*Cough* COD *Cough*)
-Cool and awesome visuals
-Game World is BIG, Really BIG
- Interesting skill progression tree
-HEAPs of guns
-Awesome and Strong Antagonist
-A good story (unlike Borderlands 1)
-Creative enemies
-CLAPTRAP
-F♥♥KLoads of guns

Cons
-You can't share you loot in multiplayer
-Not enough Guns
-Texture Pop-in here and there
-No Saving if you want to at a specific time
-Sometimes message interrupt and other messages don't get heard

Overall, this game is amazing and 1 of the best games of 2012, along with 'The Walking Dead: Season 1' and Far Cry 3 and many others. This is definitely a must-buy either at full price or if you are like me during a sale, either way BUY THIS GAME! Did I mention it had a lot of guns?

Rating: MUST BUY!
Final Verdict: 9.2/10

reviewText: Grab your friends, give them shootalots and get into da choppa... or atleast bandit roadrunner.\n\nHaving played Borderlands 1 over and over, then jumping onto Borderlands 2 expecting the same mayhem of flying bullets and screaming psychos, I definetely found what I looked for and expected from second installment. Game reintroduces our old Vault Hunters from previous game as NPCs with the feel of nostalgia, we get to play 4 new base heroes with simmiliar mechanics to old ones and introduces two more heroes with brand new mechanics which were made with support and feedback of fanbase since we all were trigger happy in Borderlands 1. We are carried through planet Pandora once again to show us what changed in meantime, then we get to know more and more of Handsome Jack, one of best developed villains of all times (next to Vaas from Far Cry 3). During game we get to shoot out all our happiness, frustration, we laugh a lot and sometimes feel sad, all because of very good made story, which rarely happens in shooter games nowadays.

reviewText: The hook of Borderlands 2,  is the loot. Guns, ammo, character skins, grenade mods, class mods -- there’s always something just a bit better, something you so desperately didn’t even know you needed until you found it in Borderlands 2. Just like other action RPGs, the hunt for loot becomes intoxicating because of the tiny rush you get each time a rare colored item spills out of a chest or recetly slain enemy. Guns are a bulk of the loot, and that’s great because you’re going to spend most of your time in Borderlands 2 staring down a gun sight.You simply have to decide the best -- or most entertaining -- way to kill everyone. Borderlands 2 is a much needed improvements to areas like narrative and class skill design to Borderlands. Overall this is an amazing shooter no one even remotely curious should overlook.

reviewText:
It's just fun.

A humorous game full of guns, with multiple classes, each providing their own unique playstyle, and abilities.

Along with a story that, if you allow it to be, is very deep, dark, and interesting to follow. However doing so is not required in order to have a good time. As someone who bought the game having not yet played the first, I was able to keep up with, and enjoy everything that was going on just fine.

The array of enemies, and bosses, ranging from robots, to bonerfarts, that can often challenge you to using different types of weaponry, or tactics in order to defeat easily.

Rather you play cooperatively, or alone, there is a lot of entertainment to be had.

Buy it. Go. Do it. Yes. Okay? Okay.

10/10

reviewText:
Borderlands 2 (BL2) is the only game I’ve ever preordered, and I definitely understand why people say Game of the Year editions punish loyal customers and early buyers. The game is amazing but if I want to get the DLC, I’ll have to spend more than the actual game costs! I guess I’ll have to wait until the GOTY edition is really cheap and upgrade my game.

BL2 is a first person shooter where you play as one of 4 (6 if you have the DLC) Vault Hunters on the planet Pandora. The story takes place sometime after the events of Borderlands 1 (maybe a few years) and quite a few characters from the first game show up in BL2. The game is world is very large and exploring everything is an exhausting but worthwhile job. You can learn a lot about the game by listening to hidden audio recordings or talking with NPCs. There’s quite a lot of humor in the game so it’s never dull. The boss especially, Handsome Jack, has tons of insults and stories to throw your way.

As for gameplay, BL2 has a level system so I guess you could call it an RPG. Each level you get a skill point to put into 1 of about 45 different skills depending on your character. You can re-spec your skills at any time so you really only need 1 of each class to experience all the play styles. There are a few vehicles that you can drive depending on what area you’re in (travel can take forever if you’re on foot). BL2 has built in multiplayer so your friends can drop in or out at any time. Just like in the first game, if you’re “killed” you have about 5 seconds to Fight For Your Life. Kill any enemy during these 5 seconds and you’re revived. If you fail Fight For Your Life, you respawn at the nearest New-U kiosk (you don’t save or load the game manually). If you have a friend in the game, he can revive you during Fight For Your Life and you won’t have to respawn.

Like the Diablo games, when you beat the game on normal mode, you can choose to replay on an increased difficulty level where both you and the enemies are higher level. Better gear will drop and almost all the enemies will gain resistances to various weapon types. This “True Vault Hunter Mode” gets insanely hard by the end of the game and you pretty much have to have a friend or 2 backing you up. BL2 is one of the few games that I’ve played through completely on coop with a friend and it definitely improves the experience.

Overall I would definitely recommend Borderlands 2 to anyone who enjoys First Person Shooters or Action RPGs (I’ve got over 200 hours in this game). The story and combat are amazingly well done as is the humor and variety. However, definitely look for a “complete edition” since the Game of the Year edition actually doesn’t include all the DLC. I think Greenmangaming had a complete edition a week or so ago which included not only the Season Pass, but also both new characters and the Ultimate Vault Hunter upgrades (increasing the level cap and introducing new weapon types).

reviewText: Borderlands 2 takes game play mechanics from FPS like Halo and adds RPG elements of a game like Diablo. The game is very entertaining and can keep you playing for long periods of time. The story is average but the sense of humor makes up for it. Borderlands 2 has one of the most original visual styles of any game I have played in the last few years, with its concept art-style appearance and thick black lines evoking the look of a graphic novel.\nBottom line: there is a reason  Borderlands 2 was one of the best selling games of 2012, and has become the best-selling game in the history of 2K Games.\n

reviewText: I have put well over 1000 hours into this game and I still go back for more. Anyone who hasn't picked this up yet should do so, I reccomend picking up as much of the DLC as you can too. This will always be one of my favorite games and i'll still be playing it for years to come.
